tree, fire hydrant, bridge, pavement, sidewalk, crosswalk or public building
without the consent and authorization of the appropriate official. This shall
not be construed as preventing any public officer or official from doing any
lawfully authorized act;
   D.   Mutilate, deface, conceal or tear down any official sign, notice or
placard posted by the city unless permission is given by a city officer or
employee to remove the notice;
   E.   Destroy, damage or in any manner alter or deface any drinking fountain
or public toilet or restroom or deposit or throw any substance in any public
toilet which causes or may cause damage to it or put any substance in a water
fountain which may pollute its waters. For purposes of this division, the terms
DRINKING FOUNTAIN and PUBLIC TOILET shall mean any facilities owned or operated
by the city or a governmental unit as well as facilities owned by private
businesses where the facilities are available for use by the public;
   F.   Open or attempt to open, interfere with or damage any fire hydrant
without authority; and/or
   G.   Maliciously and willfully, by and with the aid and use of any key,
instrument, device or explosives, blows or attempts to blow or forces or
attempts to force an entrance into any coin box, depository box, automated
teller machine (or “ATM”) or other receptacle established and maintained for
the convenience of the public or of any person or persons, in making payment
for any article of merchandise or service, wherein is continued any money or
thing of value or extracts or obtains or attempts to extract or obtain,
therefrom any money or thing of value so deposited or contained therein.
Sec. 22-7. LITTERING AND WASTE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to:
   A.   Knowingly, without the consent of the public authority having
supervision of any public property or the owner of private property, dump,
deposit, place, throw or leave or cause or permit the dumping, depositing,
placing, throwing or leaving of, litter on public or private property or water
other than property designated and set aside for the purposes or on city
streets as directed by the city during designated clean-up period. For purposes
of this division, PUBLIC OR PRIVATE PROPERTY OR WATER includes, but is not
limited to, the right-of-way of a road or highway: a body of water or
watercourse or the shore or beach (including the ice above the water); city
parks or playgrounds; refuge, conservation or recreation areas; and residential
or farm properties or timberlands;
   B.   Knowingly fail to remove a vehicle, of any nature, wrecked or damaged
in an accident on a highway, road or street or fail to remove all glass and
other injurious substance dropped on the highway, road or street as a result of
an accident;
   C.   Knowingly cause any litter or any object to fall or to be thrown into
the path of or to hit a vehicle, of any nature traveling the highway;
   D.   A person who violates any provision of this chapter is responsible for
a municipal civil infraction, as defined herein. Repeat offenses shall be
subject to increased fines as provided by this code; and/or
   E.   No person shall leave outside of any building or dwelling or in a place
accessible to children, any abandoned, unattended or discarded icebox,
refrigerator, trunk, chest, cooler cabinet or any other container of any kind
which has an airtight door or lock which may not be released for opening from
the inside of the icebox, refrigerator, trunk, chest cooler, cabinet or other
container, without first removing the locks or doors therefrom.
Sec. 22-8. THEFT OFFENSES.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to:
   A.   Obtain or attempt to obtain money, goods, property or services by
fraud, trick or false pretenses;
   B.   Knowingly obtain or attempt to obtain telephone service or the
transmission of a telephone message by the use of any false or fictitious
telephone credit number or telephone number of another without the authority of
the person to whom the credit number or telephone number was issued;
   C.   Buy, receive, possess, conceal or aid in the concealment of stolen,
embezzled or converted money, goods or property, knowing the money, goods or
property to be stolen, embezzled or converted;
   D.   Refuse or willfully neglect to return a motor vehicle, trailer or other
tangible property, which he or she has on a rental or lease basis under any
agreement in writing providing for its return to a particular place at a
particular time, after the expiration of the time stated in a written notice
proved to have been duly mailed by registered or certified mail addressed to
the last known address of the person who rented or leased the motor vehicle,
trailer or other tangible property and with intent to defraud the lessor;
   E.   As the agent, servant or employee of another or as the trustee, bailee
or custodian of the property of another or of any partnership, voluntary
association, public or private corporation or of this state or of any county,
city, village, township or school district within the state, fraudulently
dispose of or convert to his or her own use or take or secrete with intent to
convert to his or her own use without the consent of his or her principal, any
money or other personal property, of his or her principal which shall have come
to his or her possession or shall be under his or her charge or control by
virtue of his or her being the agent, servant, employee, trustee, bailee or
custodian;
   F.   By use of a computer, telephone or other electronic or mechanical
device, obtain or gain access to any database, confidential records or other
information not his or her own without permission of the owner or keeper of the
information;
   G.   Telephone, e-mail or other electronic device in a false order to any
food delivery service or a false request to any service business and request
that food be delivered to a location or that services be rendered at a
particular location;
   H.   With intent to defraud, make or draw or utter or deliver any check,
draft or order for the payment of money, to apply on account or otherwise, upon
any bank or other depository, knowing at the time of the making, drawing,
uttering or delivering, that the maker or drawer, has not sufficient funds in
or credit with the bank or other depository, for the payment of the check,
draft or order, in full upon its presentation, if the amount payable in the
check, draft or order is for any amount;
   I.   With intent to defraud, make, draw, utter or deliver any check, draft
or order for the payment of money to apply on account or otherwise, upon any
bank or other depository and who shall not have sufficient funds for the
payment for same when presentment is made to the drawee, except where the lack
of funds is due to garnishment, attachment, levy or other lawful cause and the
fact was not known to the person who made, draw, uttered or delivered the
instrument at the time of so doing if the amount payment in the check, draft or
order is for any amount;
   J.   As against the maker or drawer thereof, the making drawing, uttering or
delivering of a check, draft or order payment of which is drawer, when
presented in the usual course of business evidence of intent to defraud and of
knowledge of insufficient funds in or credit with the bank or other depository;
provided, the maker or drawer shall not have paid the drawer thereof the amount
due thereon, together with all costs and protest fees, within days after
receiving notice that the check, draft or order has not been paid by the
drawee;
   K.   With regard to divisions H., I. or J. above, where the check draft or
order is protested on the ground of insufficiency of funds or credit, the
notice of protest shall be admissible a proof of presentation, nonpayment and
protest, shall be prima facie evidence of intent to defraud and of knowledge of
insufficient funds or credit with the bank or other depository;
   L.   Take, in any way, from the public library any book, pamphlet, map,
chart, painting, picture, photograph, periodical, newspaper, magazine,
manuscript or exhibit or any part thereof, with intent to convert the same to
his or her own use or with intent to defraud the owner thereof or who having
procured or taken any book, pamphlet, map, chart, painting, picture,
photograph, periodical, newspaper, magazine, manuscript or exhibit or any part
thereof, shall thereafter convert the same to his or her own use or
fraudulently deprive the owner thereof, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor; and/
or
   M.   Taking or injuring fruit, shade, ornamental trees, shrubs, vines. Any
person who shall wrongfully take and carry away from any place any fruit tree,
ornamental, tree, shade tree, ornamental shrub or any plant, vine, bush or
vegetable there growing, standing or being, with intent to deprive the owner
thereof or who shall, without right and with wrongful intent, detach from the
ground or injure any fruit tree, ornamental tree, shade tree, ornamental shrub
or any plant, vine, bush, vegetable or produce shall be deemed by so doing to
have committed the crime of larceny and shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
ARTICLE IV. ALCOHOL AND DRUG OFFENSES
Sec. 22-9. GENERAL PROVISIONS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to:
   A.   Be intoxicated or under the influence of an alcoholic beverage, any
drug or any combination of alcoholic beverages and drugs in any public place
and either endanger directly the safety of another person or property or act in
a manner that causes or creates a public disturbance;
   B.   Sell, give or furnish any drug to any person without a license to sell,
give or furnish a drug; and/or
   C.   Possess or use a drug unless otherwise expressly permitted or licensed
by federal or state law.
Sec. 22-10. DRUG PARAPHERNALIA.
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to:
      1.   Use or possess with intent to use, drug paraphernalia to plant,
propagate, cultivate, grow, harvest, manufacture, compound, convert, produce,
process, prepare, test, analyze, pack, repack, store, contain, conceal, inject,
ingest, inhale or otherwise introduce into the human body a drug in violation
of this chapter;
      2.   Deliver or possess with intent to deliver, drug paraphernalia,
knowing or under circumstances where one reasonably should know, that it will
be used to plant, propagate, cultivate, grow, harvest, manufacture, compound,
convert, produce, process, prepare, test, analyze, pack, repack, store,
contain, conceal, inject, ingest, inhale or otherwise introduce into the human
body a drug in violation of this chapter; and/or
      3.   Place in any newspaper, magazine, handbill or other publication any
advertisement, knowing or under circumstances where one reasonably should know,
that the purpose of the advertisement, in whole or in part, is to promote the
sale of objects designed or intended for use as drug paraphernalia.
   B.   This section shall not apply to a law enforcement officer who, in the
course of his or her duties, is required to perform certain acts in
investigating illegal drug traffic, nor shall it include a person for whom
marijuana has been prescribed by a physician, duly licensed by the state or a
person who, in the lawful course of his or her business, is required to handle
the items.
Sec. 22-11. POSSESSION OR USE OF MARIJUANA.
   No person who has not obtained a registration from the Michigan Department
of Community Health and complies with the Michigan Medical Marijuana Act (MMMA)
of 2008 shall knowingly or intentionally possess or use marijuana.
   A.   This section shall not apply to a Qualifying Patient who possesses a
caregiver or patient medical marijuana card and complies with M.C.L.A.
§§ 333.26421 et seq. of MMMA.
   B. When any person who has not previously been convicted of any offense
under this chapter or under any statute of the United States or of any state
relating to narcotic drugs coca leaves, marijuana or stimulant, depressant or
hallucinogenic drugs, pleads guilty to or is found guilty of possession or use
of marijuana, the court, without entering judgment of guilty and with the
consent of the accused may defer further proceedings and place the person or
probation upon reasonable terms and conditions. Upon violation of a term or
condition imposed, the court may enter an adjudication of guilty and proceed as
otherwise provided. Upon fulfillment of the terms and conditions, this court
shall discharge the person and dismiss the proceedings against him or her.
Discharge and dismissal, under this section, shall be without an adjudication
of guilt. There may be only one discharge and dismissal under this division
granted to any person.
ARTICLE V. OFFENSES AGAINST THE PUBLIC PEACE
Sec. 22-12. DISTURBANCE OF THE PEACE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to:
   A.   Create or engage in any disturbance, fight or quarrel in any public
place, except in reasonable self-defense when attacked without reasonable
provocation, or in reasonable defense of another who was so attacked;
   B.   Disturb the public peace and quiet by loud, boisterous or vulgar
conduct or language, which can be heard by persons at a distance of 50 feet
from the location where the conduct or language originates;
   C.   Without proper authority, conduct himself or herself in any public
place so as to obstruct the free and uninterrupted passage of the public;
   D.   Disturb or unreasonably interfere with any service of worship or other
assembly gathered for lawful purpose;
     E.   Fire, discharge, display or possess any fireworks except of the type
and under the conditions expressly permitted by state law and this code of
ordinances;
   F.   Incite, cause or attempt to incite or cause any assembled group of
persons to act in a manner that is likely to or does endanger the safety of
another person or of property; and/or
   G.   By the use or means of telephone, perform any of the following:
      1.   Disturb the peace, quiet or privacy of any other person by repeated
calls intended to harass or annoy the person or family to whom the calls are
made;
      2.   Use obscene or offensive language or suggest any lewd or lascivious
act;
      3.   Attempt to extort money or anything of value from any person;
      4.   Threaten any physical violence or harm to any person;
      5.   Repeatedly and continuously ring the telephone of any person with
intent to disturb or harass the person;
   H.   Except as permitted at events approved, from time to time, by
resolution of the City Council, create any loud noises or use any loudspeaker,
sound amplifier, or other electrical or mechanical device intended to increase
the volume of sound which can be heard by persons at a distance of 50 feet from
the location where the sound originates, and which disturbs the quiet, comfort
or repose of any person or persons; and/or
   I.   It shall be unlawful, from 9:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. in a residential
district or from 10:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. in commercial district, to disturb the
public quiet, comfort or repose of any person or persons by making, creating or
causing any loud, unnecessary or unusual noise that can be heard by a person at
a distance of 50 feet from the location or property line where the sound
originates.
(Ord. 360, adopted 9-12-2011)
Sec. 22-13. VICE OFFENSES.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to:
   A.   Engage in prostitution or solicit or accost any person for the purpose
of inducing the commission of prostitution or any illegal or immoral act;
   B.   Engage in gambling or any game of chance for money, except as otherwise
expressly permitted by law;
   C.   Attend, frequent, operate or be an occupant of any place where
prostitution, gambling, the illegal sale or use of alcoholic beverages, drugs
or any other illegal or immoral business or occupation is permitted or
conducted;
   D.   Knowingly transport any person to any place for the purpose of enabling
the person to engage in gambling, prostitution or in any illegal act;
   E.   Keep, maintain or permit the use of a gambling room, table, equipment
or pool tickets, to be used for gambling on any premises occupied or controlled
by him or her; and/or
   F.   Permit or allow any premises owned, occupied or controlled by him or
her to he occupied by persons engaging in any act of prostitution.
Sec. 22-14. CURFEW.
   A.   Minor under 17. No minor under the age of 17 years shall congregate,
traverse or remain in or upon any public street, highway, alley or other public
place between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., except where the minor is
accompanied by a parent or guardian or some adult delegated by the parent or
guardian to accompany the minor child or where the minor is upon an errand or
other legitimate business directed by his or her parent or guardian.
   B.   Aiding and abetting violation. No person who is 17 years or over shall
assist, aid, abet or encourage any minor under the age of 17 years to violate
the provisions of divisions A., B. or C. herein.
   C.   Parents, guardians, etc. No parent, guardian or other person having the
legal care and custody of any minor under the age of 17 years shall knowingly
allow, permit or encourage that minor, while in his or her legal custody, to
congregate, traverse or remain in or upon any public street, highway, alley or
other public place as prohibited in divisions A., B. and C. herein.
   D.   Exceptions. The provisions of this section shall not apply to persons
traveling to or from their homes, places of employment or an activity sponsored
or sanctioned by a school, civic group, church or licensee of the city at which
no alcoholic liquor or alcoholic beverages are served.
Sec. 22-15. MISCELLANEOUS OFFENSES.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to:
   A.   Engage in any window peeping;
   B.   Swim or bathe in the nude in any public place or on private property
without the specific permission of the owner;
   C.   Expectorate, urinate, defecate or perform any other act which creates a
hazardous, unsanitary or deleterious condition in any public place or upon the
property of any other person. This division shall not apply to the property use
of public or private restroom facilities; and/or
   D.   Tell or pretend to tell fortunes by person, machine or otherwise for
hire, gain, reward or profit, whether by means of cards, tokens, trances,
inspection of the hands or skull mind reading, consulting the movements of the
heavenly bodies or otherwise.
Sec. 22-16. WEAPONS.
   A.   Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following terms
shall be defined as provided below:
      AUTHORIZED AREA. An authorized target range, or other property where
firearms may be discharged, or on or within private property with the
permission of the owner or possessor of that property.
      AUTHORIZED TARGET RANGE. A gun or archery range with all applicable
licenses, permits, and approvals.
      BOW. A device for propelling an arrow from a string drawn, held, and
released by hand if the force used to hold the string in the drawn position is
provided by the archer’s muscles.
      CONCEAL. To intentionally hide, put out of sight, disguise, or do any
other act to keep an object out of sight and to avoid its being discovered or
observed.
      CROSSBOW. A weapon consisting of a bow, with the draw weight of 100
pounds or more, mounted transversely on a stock or frame and designed to fire
an arrow, bolt, or quarrel by the release of a bow string controlled by a
mechanical or electric trigger with a working safety.
      DANGEROUS STABBING WEAPON. A knife with a blade in excess of four inches,
a knife having the appearance of a pocket knife with a blade that can be opened
by the flick of a button, a dagger, dirk, stiletto, sword, or similar dangerous
weapon used for cutting or piercing.
      FIREARM. Any weapon which will, is designed to, or may readily be
converted to expel a projectile by action of an explosive.
      PNEUMATIC GUN. Any implement, designed as a gun, that will expel a BB or
pellet by spring, gas, or air. PNEUMATIC GUN includes a paintball gun that
expels by pneumatic pressure plastic balls filled with paint for the purpose of
marking the point of impact.
      POSSESS. Carrying or having control over an object with knowledge of its
presence.
      PUBLIC BUILDING. A building owned and/or controlled by the city and
located in the city.
   B.   Discharge of dangerous weapons. No person shall discharge any firearm,
bow, cross bar, or pneumatic weapon except for as follows:
      1.   Authorized law enforcement officers are permitted to discharge
firearms in the performance of their duties.
      2.   A person may discharge a firearm, bow, crossbow, or pneumatic weapon
for the lawful protection of life or property.
      3.   A person may discharge a firearm, bow, or crossbow for target
practice purposes, in a safe manner in an authorized target range.
      4.   A person may discharge a pneumatic gun in any authorized area if
such person exercises reasonable care to prevent a projectile from crossing the
bounds of the property.
      5.   The City Council has determined that the city is sufficiently
populated such that all conduct in violation of this section would be dangerous
to the inhabitants of the city.
   C.   Possession of knives and dangerous stabbing weapons by minors. No
person under 18 years of age shall possess or control, except within his or her
own domicile, a dangerous stabbing weapon. However, such person shall not be in
violation of this section if:
      1.   The person is at or in route to or from a place of employment where
use of such dangerous stabbing weapon is necessary; or
      2.   The person is accompanied by a parent, guardian, or other
responsible adult and is at or in route to or from a place of hunting, trapping
or fishing and, whenever required, is carrying a valid license for such weapon.
   D.   Possession of dangerous stabbing weapons in public buildings. No person
shall possess or conceal any dangerous stabbing weapon in a public building.
However, this section shall not apply to any law enforcement officer carrying a
weapon issued or authorized for use on the job by the officer’s employer.
   E.   Projectiles from vehicles. No person shall throw or propel any
snowball, missile, or other object from a moving vehicle in the direction of a
person or vehicle, or onto the private property of another.
   F.   Hunting or trapping. No person shall hunt or trap animals within the
city.
(Ord. 377, passed 10-24-2016)
Sec. 22-17. PUBLIC NUDITY.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly or intentionally display in
a public place or, for payment or promise of payment including, but not limited
to, payment or promise of payment of an admission fee, to knowingly or
intentionally display in any other place any individual’s genitals or anus with
less than fully opaque covering or a female individual’s breast with less than
a fully opaque covering of the nipple and areola. Public nudity does not
include any of the following:
   A.   A woman’s breastfeeding of an infant shall not under any circumstances
constitute public nudity irrespective of whether the nipple is covered during
or incidental to the feeding;
   B.   “Material” defined in § 2 of Public Act 343 of 1984, as amended, being
M.C.L.A. § 752.362;
   C.   “Sexually explicit visual material” as defined in § 3 of Public Act 33
of 1978, as amended, being M.C.L.A. § 722.673;
   D.   Any display of any part of the anatomy occurring as part of the regular
curriculum of an educational institution that is funded, chartered or
recognized by the state; and/or
   E.   Any modeling session for a local, nonprofit organization, that is not
open to the public or to any persons other than members of the organization,
that is for the purpose of instruction in the artistic depiction in two-
dimensional or three-dimensional media of the human form and during which the
model remains in a fixed pose.
ARTICLE VI. OFFENSES AGAINST GOVERNMENT ORDER
Sec. 22-18. GENERAL PROVISIONS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to:
   A.   Use any physical or verbal conduct which obstructs, resists, hinders or
opposes any member of the Police or Fire Department or any other peace officer,
in the lawful discharge of his or her duties;
   B.   Knowingly furnish to any city official or employee, acting in the
lawful discharge of his or her duties, a false name, address, date of birth or
a false of misleading report in connection with an arrest or the investigation
of an alleged commission of any crime, misdemeanor or citation;
   C.   Escape or attempt to escape while lawfully in the custody of any police
or other peace officer;
   D.   Impersonate, with due authority, a firefighter, police or other peace
officer or other governmental officer or employee;
   E.   Knowingly report a false alarm of fire;
   F.   Any person who shall willfully and knowingly make to any police
officer, a fictitious report of the commission of any crime knowing the same to
be false, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. If the report of fictitious crime
relates to a bombing, an attempted bombing or a threat to bomb and the report
shall be willfully and knowingly communicated to any peace officer or to any
other person, then the person making the fictitious report shall be deemed to
be guilty of a misdemeanor;
   G.   A person who, with the intent not to use the assistance, knowingly
causes or makes a request for the assistance of an ambulance service or an
advanced mobile emergency care service is guilty of a misdemeanor;
   H.   When operating a motor vehicle which has been stopped in response to a
police officer’s signal, leave or attempt to leave the scene unless and until
he or she has received permission to do so from the officer;
   I.   Falsely indicate a lack of knowledge or, when asked by a law
enforcement officer, a prosecuting attorney, the City Attorney or a Judge, fail
to disclose or conceal knowledge of the actual commission of a violation of
this chapter from a court of law or from a law enforcement officer
investigating the violation. This division shall not be interpreted to conflict
with the right of any person not to be a witness against himself or herself or
any other legally recognized privilege or right;
   J.   Willfully fail to obey the command of any properly identified law
enforcement officer to stop or halt;
   K.   Willfully fail to obey the command of any police officer who is
directing traffic or engaging in crowd control;
   L.   Willfully fail to obey the command of any law enforcement officer,
school official or other authorized representative of the Department, to leave
a public park, school grounds, playground, boulevard, swimming pool or
recreation area when ordered to do so;
   M.   Stand, sit, kneel, lie, loiter or walk upon or occupy the traveled
portion of any roadway, except when necessary to avoid contact with any vehicle
lawfully on the roadway.
      1.   Where there are no adjacent sidewalks, a person may, without
violating this provision, walk along the left edge of the traveled portion of
the roadway in a manner so as to be facing traffic.
      2.   Walking, as provided in division M.1. above shall be in a “single
file” so that two or more persons are not walking abreast.
   N.   Sitting or standing in a drive aisle in any public parking lot. This
provision does not apply to a person standing in a drive aisle while
momentarily waiting for access to a vehicle in that parking lot or while
loading or unloading items in a vehicle in that parking lot;
   O.   Repeatedly travel in a motor vehicle over one or more city streets with
no destination or without stopping at any destination. For purposes of this
division, if the vehicle passes the same place on a street three times within
one hour, there shall be a presumption of the offensive conduct;
   P.   Interfere with any person’s use of public streets, sidewalks, public
places or places open to the general public; and/or
   Q.   Travel or stand in a motor vehicle in a slow manner, in a repeated
route or in another manner so as to impede or interfere with the travel on or
use of any street, road, parking lot or right-of-way by any other vehicles.
Sec. 22-19. OFFENSES ON SCHOOL PROPERTY.
   It shall be unlawful to:
   A.   Entry upon school property:
      1.   Enter into or upon any public, private or parochial building or
school property in the city for any reason whatsoever, unless the person has
received permission from the principal or other person designated by the
principal to be in or upon or to remain in or upon the public, private or
parochial school building or school property or is otherwise so permitted by
law; and/or
      2.   This division shall not apply to persons engaging in or attending a
school for an authorized activity or to persons using a school playground or
playground equipment after school hours or when school is not in session,
unless the entry or use shall have been otherwise prohibited by a published or
posted rule or regulation of the school board, school principal or other
person, board or committee with the authority to prohibit the use or entry.
   B.   Making or assisting in making any noise, disturbance or improper
diversion by which the peace, quietude or good order of any public, private or
parochial school is disturbed;
   C.   Failing to leave the building or property, immediately when so directed
by the principal or by any other person designated by the principal or other
school personnel;
   D.   By violence, threats of violence or other form of coercion, force or
attempts to force any public, private or parochial school student or other
person to give or to lend any money or other thing of value to any person at
any time; and/or
   E.   Damage, destroy, mark or deface any public, private or parochial school
building or other grounds, outbuildings, fences, trees or other appurtenances
or fixtures belonging thereto.
ARTICLE VII. VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES
Sec. 22-20. VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES.
   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter is responsible for a
municipal civil infraction, subject to payment of a civil fine of not less than
$250, plus costs and other sanctions, for each violation. Repeat offenses shall
be subject to increased fines as provided by code, except that the increased
fine for a repeat offense shall be as follows.
   A.   The fine for any offense which is a first repeat offense shall be not
less than $500, plus costs and other sanctions.
   B.   The fine for any offense which is a second repeat offense or any
subsequent repeat offense shall be not less than $1,000, plus costs and other
sanctions.
CHAPTER 23: FIREWORKS
Section
   
23-1   Code and amendments and revisions adopted
   
23-2   References in code
   
23-3   Violations and penalties
Sec. 23-1. CODE AND AMENDMENTS AND REVISIONS ADOPTED.
   Michigan Fireworks Safety Act, Act 256 of 2011, M.C.L.A. 28.450 et seq.,
effective January 1, 2012 as amended, is incorporated by reference.
(Ord. 367, adopted 8-25-2014)
Sec. 23-2. REFERENCES IN CODE.
   References in the Michigan Fireworks Safety Act to a “governmental unit”
shall mean the “city”.
(Ord. 367, adopted 8-25-2014)
Sec. 23-3. VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES.
   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter is responsible for a
municipal civil infraction, subject to payment of a civil fine of not less than
$250, plus costs and other sanctions, for each violation.
Repeat offenses shall be subject to increased fines as provided by code, except
that the increased fine for a repeat offense shall be as follows.
   A.   The fine for any offense which is a first repeat offense shall be not
less than $500, plus costs and other sanctions.
   B.   The fine for any offense which is a second repeat offense or any
subsequent repeat offense shall be not less than $1,000, plus costs and other
sanctions.
(Ord. 367, adopted 8-25-2014)
CHAPTER 24: FRISBEES; SKATEBOARDS; ROLLERSKATES
Section
   
24-1   Regulations
   
24-2   Purpose
   
24-3   Definitions
   
24-4   Prohibited uses
   
24-5   Violations and penalties
Sec. 24-1. REGULATIONS.
   A chapter to regulate frisbees, skateboards, rollerskate and rollerskates.
(Ord. 234, adopted 6-9-1986)
Sec. 24-2. PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to ensure the safe and convenient use of the
public highways, streets, alleys, sidewalks and footpaths of the city.
(Ord. 234, adopted 6-9-1986)
Sec. 24-3. DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   FRISBEE. Any saucer shaped disc used for skimming into the air.
   ROLLERSKATE. Any shoe like device with wheels attached.
   SKATEBOARD. Any board like object with wheels attached.
(Ord. 234, adopted 6-9-1986)
Sec. 24-4. PROHIBITED USES.
   A.   No person shall ride or in any manner use a skateboard, rollerskate or
rollerskates, upon the following public ways:
      1.   Main Street between Chart Street and North Main Street Bridge;
      2.   East Bridge Street (M-89) between Anderson Street and Main Street;
      3.   Allegan Street (M-89) between Millrace Bridge and Main Street;
      4.   West Bridge Street between Millrace Bridge and Main Street;
      5.   Any city owned/leased or maintained parking lot;
      6.   The sidewalks running along the public ways set forth in divisions
A.1. through 5. above;
      7.   The city boardwalk and sidewalks within any public park unless
designated for that use.
   B.   No person shall ride on or in any manner use a skateboard, rollerskate
or rollerskates, with a sail.
   C.   No person shall ride on or in any manner use a skateboard, rollerskate
or rollerskates, which is being towed by any vehicle or animal.
   D.   No person shall throw, cause to be thrown or participate in any manner
in the throwing of a frisbee on a public highway, street, alley, sidewalk or
footpath.
   E.   No person shall throw, cause to be thrown or participate in any manner
in the throwing of a frisbee in a manner as to interfere with the lawful use of
public highway, street, alley, sidewalk or footpath.
   F.   This chapter shall not be construed to prohibit the use of frisbees in
other areas; provided that, the use does not interfere with the lawful use of a
public highway, street, alley, sidewalk or footpath.
(Ord. 234, adopted 6-9-1986)
Sec. 24-5. VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES.
   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter is responsible for a
municipal civil infraction, subject to payment of a civil fine of not less than
$100, plus costs and other sanctions, for each violation. Repeat offenses shall
be subject to increased fines as provided by code, except that the increased
fine for a repeat offense shall be as follows.
   A.   The fine for any offense which is a first repeat offense shall be not
less than $500, plus costs and other sanctions.
   B.   The fine for any offense which is a second repeat offense or any
subsequent repeat offense shall be not less than $1,000, plus costs and other
sanctions.
(Ord. 234, adopted 6-9-1986; Ord. 318, adopted 11-12-2001)
CHAPTER 25: NUISANCES
Section
   
25-1   Offensive matter, trades
   
25-2   Offensive substances on sidewalks, streets or alleys
   
25-3   Offensive structures
   
25-4   Litter, debris, hazards; private property
   
25-5   Authority to inspect and report
   
25-6   Removal of nuisance
   
25-7   Violations and penalties
   
25-8   Nuisances prohibited
Sec. 25-1. OFFENSIVE MATTER, TRADES.
   It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to keep in or about any shop,
dwelling or premises owned or occupied by him, her or them within the limits of
the city any offensive animal or vegetable matter or within the limits of the
city to engage in or carry on any filthy or loathsome trade or occupation that
may be prejudicial to health therein.
(Ords. 11 and 135, readopted 12-31-1965)
Sec. 25-2. OFFENSIVE SUBSTANCES ON SIDEWALKS, STREETS OR ALLEYS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, suffer, cause or permit to be
thrown on any sidewalk or into any street or alley within the limits of the
city any urine, carrion, slops, filthy water or filthy substance or suffer or
permit the same to pass through any drain onto any sidewalk or any street or
alley within the limits of the city.
(Ords. 11 and 135, readopted 12-31-1965)
Sec. 25-3. OFFENSIVE STRUCTURES.
   It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to erect or continue or cause
to be continued any privy, hog sty, cow pen, stable or any nuisance within the
limits of the city in any manner so the same shall be injurious to the public
health or so near to another lot or lots as to materially impair the comfort of
any person occupying other lot or lots, but the nuisance or the injury
occasioned by the same shall be removed within 24 hours by the owner or
occupant of the lot or premises upon which the same exists after being notified
by the Superintendent of the Department of Public Works or designee in writing
to remove or cause the removal of the same.
(Ords. 11 and 135, readopted 12-31-1965)
Sec. 25-4. LITTER, DEBRIS, HAZARDS; PRIVATE PROPERTY.
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any owner, occupier or person having the right
to possession of any private property to cause or permit:
      1.   Any junk, debris or waste, including, but not limited to, filth,
rubbish, refuse, garbage, offal, paper, glass, cans, bottles, dead shrubbery,
trash, dead trees or any other foreign substance to remain on the property; or
      2.   Any pollutants or hazardous materials to remain in the soil, water
or air following a release of pollutants or hazardous materials from the
property in a quantity which is or may become injurious to the public health,
safety or welfare or the environment.
      3.   It shall be unlawful and constitute a public nuisance to deposit on
the public sidewalk any snow or ice which is hazardous to pedestrians.
      4.   It shall be unlawful and constitute a public nuisance to deposit
snow or ice on neighboring right-of- ways or properties.
      5.   A person shall not deposit, or cause to be deposited, snow, ice or
slush on any roadway or highway.
      6.   For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
         HAZARDOUS MATERIAL. Any of the following:
            (1)   Hazardous substances as defined in the Comprehensive
Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act of 1980, Pub. Law No.
96-510, 94 State, 2767, as amended; or as defined in Part 201 of Public Act 451
of 1994, as amended; or as defined under other local, state or federal laws,
rules or regulations;
            (2)   Hazardous waste as defined under 40 C.F.R. Part 261; or as
defined under Part 111 of Public Act 451 of 1994, as amended; or as defined
under other local, state or federal laws, rules or regulations;
            (3)   Any material defined or listed as a toxic waste or pollutant
in 40 C.F.R. § 401.15; in the Critical Materials Register promulgated by the
State Department of Environmental Quality: or under other local, state or
federal laws, rules or regulations;
            (4)   Petroleum as described in Part 213 of Public Act 451 of 1994,
as amended; and
            (5)   Any substance or material in quantity or form which, in the
determination of the city, pose a substantial present or potential hazard to
human life, health and safety, welfare, property or the environment and shall
include, but shall not be limited to, such substances as chemicals, explosives,
oxidizers, peroxides, poisons, radioactive materials, petroleum or petroleum
products, gases, poisons, etiologic (biologic) agents, flammables and
corrosives.
         POLLUTANT. Any material or substance added to the soil, water or air
and includes (but is not limited to) solids, residues, wastes, gases, liquids,
vapors, sludges, wastes, ash, particulate matter, biological materials,
radioactive materials, chemicals, dust and dirt; and properties of materials
(including, but not limited to, pH, odors and heat).
         RELEASE. Includes, but is not limited to, the accidental or
intentional, sudden or gradual, spilling, leaking, pumping, pouring, emitting,
emptying, discharging, injecting, escaping, leaching, dumping or disposing into
the environment or the abandonment or discarding of barrels, containers or
other receptacles containing a hazardous material.
   B.   It shall also be unlawful for any person to keep or permit upon the
land any hazard, open pit, hole, excavation, basement, abandoned refrigerator,
well, cistern or similar condition unless fenced as prescribed by the Council.
   C.   It shall also be unlawful for any person to keep or permit any grass or
weeds exceeding six inches in length upon the land or upon the following public
access areas abutting the property:
      1.   The city right-of-way on either side of a public street;
      2.   A public or utility easement to the centerline; and/or
      3.   An alley or alleyway to the centerline.
   D.   It shall be unlawful for any person by himself or herself or by aiding
or abetting another, to cause litter to exist upon any public or private
property within the city including, but not limited to, the items mentioned in
division A. hereof.
(Ord. 340, adopted 6-27-2005; Am. Ord. 365, adopted 2-10-2014)
Sec. 25-5. AUTHORITY TO INSPECT AND REPORT.
   The Superintendent of the Department of Public Works or designee is
authorized and empowered and it is declared to be his or her duty to visit and
inspect any and all premises in the city and if he or she finds thereon any
filth that, in his or her estimation, constitutes a nuisance or is injurious or
detrimental to the public health, it shall be his or her duty to report the
same to the Health Officer of the city, who shall at once visit and inspect the
same and, if in his or her judgment, the filth constitutes a nuisance or is
detrimental to the public health, he or she shall so report to the
Superintendent of the Department of Public Works or designee, of if the Health
Officer shall discover any filth within the limits of the city that is a
nuisance or is detrimental to the public health although not so reported to him
or her by the Superintendent of the Department of Public Works or designee, he
or she shall at once report the same to that officer.
(Ords. 11 and 135, readopted 12-31-1965)
Sec. 25-6. REMOVAL OF NUISANCE.
   It shall then be the duty of the Superintendent of the Department of Public
Works or designee to, at once, order the owner or occupant of the premises upon
which the filth or nuisance exists to remove the same in the time, not less
than 24 hours as he or she may prescribe in the notice and the notice shall be
in writing and shall specify the premises and the filth or nuisance ordered to
be removed. In case the occupant or owner shall refuse, neglect or fail to
remove the same within the time prescribed in the notice then, and in that
case, the Superintendent of the Department of Public Works or designee shall
cause the same to be removed, keeping an accurate account of the expense
thereof and shall as soon as practicable thereafter make and present to the
owner or occupant an itemized and sworn bill of the expenses and demand payment
thereof and if the owner or occupant fails to pay the same the Superintendent
of the Department of Public Works or designee shall return the same, with a
verified statement of the time when and the place where, he or she presented
the bill to the owner or occupants and the fact of non-payment, to the Clerk,
who shall duly file the same in his or her office and make report thereof to
the City Council and the amount of the expenses shall be a lien upon and be
levied as a tax upon the premises where the filth or nuisance existed.
(Ords. 11 and 135, readopted 12-31-1965)
Editor’s note:
   The enforcement remedy set forth in the city’s special assessment ordinance,
as amended, shall be considered cumulative to the remedy set forth herein.
Sec. 25-7. VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES.
   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter is responsible for a
municipal civil infraction, subject to payment of a civil fine of not less than
$250, plus costs and other sanctions, for each violation. Repeat offenses shall
be subject to increased fines as provided by code, except that the increased
fine for a repeat offense shall be as follows.
   A.   The fine for any offense which is a first repeat offense shall be not
less than $1,000, plus costs and other sanctions.
   B.   The fine for any offense which is a second repeat offense or any
subsequent repeat offense shall be not less than $2,500, plus costs and other
sanctions.
(Ords. 11 and 135, readopted 12-31-1965)
Sec. 25-8. NUISANCES PROHIBITED.
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, permit, maintain or allow
the creation or maintenance of a nuisance.
   B.   For purposes of this chapter, NUISANCE shall mean an act or omission
which creates or permits the existence of a situation which interferes with a
person’s use and enjoyment of his or her property, including, but not limited
to, the following:
      1.   Glare from spotlights or lighting fixtures that are mounted,
positioned or aimed so as to directly illuminate adjacent residential
properties; and
      2.   Dust crossing a property line generated from construction activity
or created by a lack of landscaping or groundcover. Construction activity does
not include ordinary yard work or lawn maintenance.
(Ord. 353, adopted 1-11-2010)
CHAPTER 26: ANIMALS
Section
   
26-1   Purpose
   
26-2   Enforcement
   
26-3   Impoundment
   
26-4   Ownership
   
26-5   Licensing and registration required generally
   
26-6   Collar and license tag to be worn
   
26-7   Licensing of impounded dogs and animals
   
26-8   Trespassing and destructive dogs and animals
   
26-9   Vicious and dangerous animals
   
26-10   Barking or howling dogs
   
26-11   Treatment of animals
   
26-12   Other animals
   
26-13   Violations and penalties
Sec. 26-1. PURPOSE.
   The purposes of this chapter are to promote the public health, safety and
general welfare of the citizens of the city and to ensure the humane treatment
of animals by regulating the care and control of animals within the city.
Sec. 26-2. ENFORCEMENT.
   A.   This chapter shall be enforced by the Public Safety Department of the
city and the Animal Control Officer of the county and any of his or her
deputies. They are hereby authorized and empowered to serve a summons for a
violation of this chapter and to issue and serve appearance tickets in lieu of
a summons for the violation.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with, prevent or
hinder any public safety or Animal Control Officer in the enforcement of this
chapter or the performance of any act required or authorized by this chapter.
Sec. 26-3. IMPOUNDMENT.
   A.   Any member of the Public Safety Department of the city or ay Animal
Control Officer of the county shall have the power and duty to seize and hold
any dog whether licensed or unlicensed, which is found off premises of its
owner in violation of this chapter.
   B.   Any member of the Public Safety Department of the city or any animal
control officer of the county shall have the power and duty to seize and hold
any dog required under this chapter to be wearing a collar or harness with a
current license, when the dog is not wearing a collar or harness with a current
license.
   C.   The authority and duty to seize and hold a dog under this section shall
include, but is not limited to, the pursuit of the dog onto private property
for the purposes of capture.
   D.   Dogs seized and held under this section shall be held at the county’s
dog pound and shall be disposed of under the rules and regulations adopted by
the county’s animal shelter, including but not limited to payment of fees,
hours of operation, licensing and care of the dog’s health.
Sec. 26-4. OWNERSHIP.
   Every person in possession of any dog and their domesticated animals and
usual household pets such as, but not by way of limitation, cats and animals as
usually obtainable in pet stores, who shall knowingly allow the animal or
animals to remain about his or her premises for a period of five days, shall be
deemed to be the owner thereof for the purposes of this chapter.
Sec. 26-5. LICENSING AND REGISTRATION REQUIRED GENERALLY.
   No resident person shall own, keep or house any dog or allowed animal within
the city unless the person shall have complied with the laws of the state and
County of Allegan providing for the licensing and registration of the dog or
animal. The number of the animals shall be as prescribed in § 
53-2.
Sec. 26-6. COLLAR AND LICENSE TAG TO BE WORN
   No resident person shall own, keep or house any dog six months old or older,
or any other animal that requires licensing and registration, that does not, at
all times when the dog or animal is off the premises of the owner, wear a
collar or harness with a license tag issued pursuant to the laws of the state
and County of Allegan.
Sec. 26-7. LICENSING OF IMPOUNDED DOGS AND ANIMALS.
   No dog, or any animal that required a license, shall be released form the
pound unless the owner or person entitled to demand the same shall procure a
license of the dog, or of the animal if a license is required of the animal, in
the manner required by the state law at the time in force and effect, in the
event that the dog or animal shall not have already been duly license.
Sec. 26-8. TRESPASSING AND DESTRUCTIVE DOGS AND ANIMALS.
   No person shall own, keep or have charge of any dog or animal which by the
destruction of property or trespassing on public property, becomes a nuisance.
It shall be unlawful to permit any animals of any age to run at large within
the corporate boundaries of the city. An animal is at large when it is off the
premises of the owner and not on a leash or otherwise under immediate control.
Sec. 26-9. VICIOUS AND DANGEROUS ANIMALS.
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to own or harbor an vicious or
dangerous animal. A vicious or dangerous animal is any animal that attacks,
bites or physically injures a human being or other animal without provocation.
   B.   The owner of any dog which has bitted a human or other animal shall
immediately place and keep the dog on a leash, even though it remains on the
owner’s property and shall immediately notify the Public Safety Department or
County Animal Control of all facts known to the owner regarding the incident.
The owner shall keep the dog continually under secure quarantine and under the
supervision and control as may be required by the Public Safety Department or
Animal Control or shall turn the dog over to the car and custody of Animal
Control for impoundment until the time as Animal Control and the Health
Department determine it is safe to release the dog, at which time all costs for
the dog’s care shall be paid by the owner to Animal Control.
SEC. 26-10. BARKING OR HOWLING DOGS.
   No person shall own, keep, house or have charge of any dog which by loud and
frequent barking, howling or yelping becomes a nuisance.
SEC. 26-11. TREATMENT OF ANIMALS.
   No person shall treat any animal in a cruel or inhuman manner, or willfully
or negligently cause or permit any animal to suffer unnecessary torture or
pain.
SEC. 26-12. OTHER ANIMALS.
   The keeping of livestock within the city is prohibited. Livestock shall
include horses, sheep, goats, pigs, cows, llamas, donkeys, mules, fowl and
other animals of a similar nature.
SEC. 26-13. VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES.
   A.   Civil infraction violations. Any person who violates any provision of
this chapter except § 
26-2B. (enforcement), § 
26-9 (vicious and dangerous animals) and § 
26-11 (treatment of animals) is responsible for a municipal civil infraction,
subject to payment of a civil fine of not less than $250, plus costs and other
sanctions, for each violation. The violator shall also be liable for all
reasonable costs incurred by the city in enforcing this chapter. Repeat
offenses shall be subject to increased fines as provided by Code, except that
the increased fine for a repeat offense shall be as follows:
      1.   The fine for any offense which is a first repeat offense shall be
not less than $500, plus costs and other sanctions.
      2.   The fine for any offense which is a second repeat offense or any
subsequent repeat offense shall be not less than $1,000, plus costs and other
sanctions.
   B.   Misdemeanors violations. Any violation of Section
26-2 B., Section
26-9 and Section
26-11 of this chapter is a misdemeanor shall, upon conviction, be punished by a
fine of net less than $100 and not more than $500 or imprisonment of not more
than 90 days in jail or by both fine and imprisonment. The violator shall also
be liable for all reasonable costs incurred by the city in enforcing this
chapter
CHAPTER 27: REFUSE BIN SAFETY STANDARD
Section
   
27-1   Definitions
   
27-2   Substandard refuse bins
   
27-3   Refuse bin requirements
   
27-4   Regulations; effective date
   
27-5   Extension
   
27-6   Violations and penalties
Sec. 27-1. DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   PERSON. A natural person, firm, partnership, association or corporation and
his, her or their legal successors.
   REFUSE BINS. Those refuse receptacles designed to be transported by or
mechanically emptied into a refuse collection vehicle and does not include
receptacles used in office buildings, businesses and single-family dwellings,
which are less than 20-gallon capacity.
   SUBSTANDARD REFUSE BINS. Those refuse bins which do not meet the stability
requirements established herein.
(Ord. 174, adopted 7-11-1977)
Sec. 27-2. SUBSTANDARD REFUSE BINS.
   All persons owning, leasing or using substandard refuse bins or permitting
the placing of the substandard refuse bins on private property within their
custody or control are encouraged to assure the early modification or
retrofitting of the substandard refuse bins or in the alternative, removal of
the bins from areas of public access.
(Ord. 174, adopted 7-11-1977)
Sec. 27-3. REFUSE BIN REQUIREMENTS.
   From and after the dates established in § 
27-4, each refuse bin shall be:
   A.   Reasonably secured in some manner, such as, secured to a stake, fence,
wall or other stationary object in a manner to prevent its tipping over;
   B.   Enclosed within a fence or barrier at least four feet high with an
access gate which is kept locked or otherwise reasonably protected from
unauthorized access; or
   C.   Designed, constructed or modified so that it will not tip when
subjected to 191 pounds hanging vertically from the leading edge thereof or to
a pull force of 70 pounds exerted horizontally from any edge thereof.
(Ord. 174, adopted 7-11-1977)
Sec. 27-4. REGULATIONS; EFFECTIVE DATE.
   Except on the basis of an extension previously recommended and approved in
accordance with this chapter, no person shall rent, lease, place upon the
property of another or permit to remain upon property within its custody or
control, any refuse bin which is not secured or protected from unauthorized
access or which does not meet the stability requirements established in the
preceding section hereof in the immediate vicinity of a school or school yard
on or after 9-2-1977; or elsewhere in the city to which the public has access
on or after 12-31-1977.
(Ord. 174, adopted 7-11-1977)
Sec. 27-5. EXTENSION.
   A fact-finding Committee appointed by the City Council may accept, consider
and make recommendations to the City Clerk upon an application from a
responsible person for an extension of the period in which to comply with the
provisions of the preceding section regarding the security of refuse bins. The
Committee, upon a showing by the applicant of diligent effort and good cause
for inability to comply with the security requirements may recommend and the
City Council may approve an extension not in excess of three months.
(Ord. 174, adopted 7-11-1977)
Sec. 27-6. VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES.
   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter is responsible for a
municipal civil infraction, subject to payment of a civil fine of not less than
$500, plus costs and other sanctions, for each violation. Repeat offenses shall
be subject to increased fines as provided by code.
(Ord. 318, adopted 11-12-2001)
CHAPTER 28: GARBAGE
Section
   
28-1    License required
   
28-2   License application
   
28-3   License approval
   
28-4   Inspection of equipment and facilities
   
28-5   License fee, term
   
28-6   Windshield sticker
   
28-7   Insurance
   
28-8   Storage
   
28-9   Transportation
   
28-10   Depositing upon private or public property
   
28-11   Garbage cans on curb lawn
   
28-12   Frequency of collection
   
28-13   Garbage cans regulated
   
28-14   Public dumping
   
28-15   Hours of collection
   
28-16   Licensees; telephone required
   
28-17   Judgments against city by reason of license granted
   
28-18   Garbage disposal dump
   
28-19   Feeding to livestock
   
28-20   Complaints; violations
   
28-21   Violations and penalties
   
28-22   License revocation
   
28-23   “Garbage” defined
Sec. 28-1. LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, association, firm or corporation to
engage in the business of collecting and disposing of garbage in the city
without first obtaining a license therefor as hereinafter provided.
(Ord. 104, adopted 4-13-1945)
Sec. 28-2. LICENSE APPLICATION.
   Application for the license shall be made in writing to the city on blanks
to be furnished by the City Clerk and the blanks shall contain in the case of
each applicant, his or her name, residence and business address, nature and
kind of business previously engaged in and places where and length of time the
same was operated, the type and model of conveyances to be used and owned by
the applicant, the location of the conveyance and the number, size and age of
garbage cans owned and to be used by the applicant, whether a can washer is to
be used by applicant and the place where the same is located and any and all
other information that may be required by the City Council to enable it to
determine the ability and qualifications of applicant to conduct such a
business in compliance with this chapter and in a manner as will not be
deleterious to the public health and welfare and so as not to create a public
or private nuisance. The application shall also contain an agreement by
applicant to abide by, to obey and comply with all the provisions of this
chapter and all other laws, ordinances, rules and regulations pertaining to the
conduct of the business now in force or which may hereafter be adopted.
(Ord. 104, adopted 4-13-1945)
Sec. 28-3. LICENSE APPROVAL.
   No license shall be granted hereunder without approval of the City Council.
(Ord. 104, adopted 4-13-1945)
Sec. 28-4. INSPECTION OF EQUIPMENT AND FACILITIES.
   No license shall be granted hereunder to any applicant until all equipment
and facilities to be used by applicant in the conduct of the business shall be
inspected and approved by the City Health Officer as to its fitness for the
purpose for which it is to be used.
(Ord. 104, adopted 4-13-1945)
Sec. 28-5. LICENSE FEE, TERM.
   Every person, association, firm or corporation who engages in the business
of collecting and disposing of garbage shall pay to the city an annual license
fee of $15. The license year shall be from May 1 to the succeeding April 30 and
the license fee shall be payable in advance; provided, the license fee upon any
license granted hereunder between January 1 and May 1 of any calendar year
shall be one-half the above amount.
(Ord. 104, adopted 4-13-1945)
Sec. 28-6. WINDSHIELD STICKER.
   Upon the granting of a license and the payment of fees required hereunder,
the City Clerk shall supply each licensee a windshield sticker for each vehicle
to be used by the licensee in the conduct of the business showing engine number
and license number of the vehicle and the sticker shall be continuously
displayed on the vehicle at all times when engaged in the collection and
transportation of garbage. No vehicle shall be used by any licensee in the
conduct of the business other than the one stated in his or her application and
for which a windshield sticker has been issued as aforesaid.
(Ord. 104, adopted 4-13-1945)
Sec. 28-7. INSURANCE.
   Before any licensee shall engage in the business of the collection and
disposal of garbage, he or she shall deposit with the city a public liability
insurance policy or policies with coverage limits not less than $100,000 for
anyone person, $300,000 for any one accident and $25,000 for property damage,
which shall be approved by the City Council, which insurance shall be kept in
full force and effect at all times during the terms of the license.
(Ord. 104, adopted 4-13-1945)
Sec. 28-8. STORAGE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to keep in, on or about the
premises owned or occupied by them any garbage or decayed vegetable matter
whatever or any swill from the house or any substance which may be injurious to
the public health, unless the same is kept in a closed covered can, as required
by the provisions of this chapter. This section shall not apply to a properly
constructed and maintained compost pile.
(Ord. 104, adopted 4-13-1945)
Sec. 28-9. TRANSPORTATION.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to carry, cart or
convey along or through the public streets of the city any garbage or decayed
vegetable matter whatever or any swill from any house or building in the city,
unless the person, association, firm or corporation is licensed hereunder.
Provided, no person shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this section when
carrying, transporting or conveying garbage in tightly enclosed cans or metal
containers over and along the public streets and alleys from his or her home to
any approved garbage dump for disposal at the dump.
(Ord. 104, adopted 4-13-1945)
Sec. 28-10. DEPOSITING UPON PRIVATE OR PUBLIC PROPERTY.
   It shall be unlawful for any licensee, person or persons, to throw or
deposit or cause to be thrown or deposited, any garbage upon any private
property, street, alley, gutter, sidewalk or public grounds in the city or in
or along the Kalamazoo River or any of the creeks within the corporate limits
of the city, except at designated places as approved by the City Health Officer
or the City Council.
(Ord. 104, adopted 4-13-1945)
Sec. 28-11. GARBAGE CANS ON CURB LAWN.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, association, firm or corporation to
place or permit to remain on any curb lawn any garbage can for any purpose
whatsoever. Provided, however, that, the can(s) may be placed on the curb lawn
on the day of the scheduled garbage pickup at that address.
(Ord. 104, adopted 4-13-1945)
Sec. 28-12. FREQUENCY OF COLLECTION.
   All garbage cans shall be collected by all licensees, from all places in the
city at least once a week in the residence portion of the city and connections
from public markets, commercial houses, hotels, hospitals, stores, stands,
restaurants and eating houses shall be made at least three times a week
throughout the year, except Sunday or at other times as the City Council shall
reasonably designate.
(Ord. 104, adopted 4-13-1945)
Sec. 28-13. GARBAGE CANS REGULATED.
   All garbage cans provided by the licensee for the use of his or her
customers shall be suitable for the purpose and shall be free from leaks and be
provided with covers so that cans may be tightly closed and any can, whenever
removed, shall be so removed as to prevent the contents or any odor from
escaping therefrom and when any can, which has contained garbage, has been
removed from the premises of any customer, the can shall be thoroughly cleaned
before the can shall be returned to the premises of any customer or again used
in the collection of garbage in the city and any vehicle drawing the cans shall
be so loaded and driven that none of the material contained therein shall fall
upon the ground or run out or spill therefrom. When any can shall be removed,
the licensee shall provide another can, which has been thoroughly cleaned, to
take the place thereof; provided that, any can which has previously been used
only for ashes or other waste material which is not garbage as termed herein,
need not be cleaned as herein provided. All garbage cans used by any licensee
shall be approved by the Health Officer and shall be withdrawn from use
whenever required so as to do by the Health Officer for the reason that the
same do not comply with the provisions of this section.
(Ord. 104, adopted 4-13-1945)
Sec. 28-14. PUBLIC DUMPING.
   It shall be unlawful for any licensee under the provisions of this chapter,
to permit or allow the dumping of cans upon the wagon or dumping from one can
into another on any wagon or in any street, alley, public place or private
property, except designated dumping places and any person or persons who shall
so dump the contents of any garbage can shall be deemed guilty of the violation
of this chapter.
(Ord. 104, adopted 4-13-1945)
Sec. 28-15. HOURS OF COLLECTION.
   There shall be no collection of garbage between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and
6:00 a.m.
(Ord. 104, adopted 4-13-1945)
Sec. 28-16. LICENSEES; TELEPHONE REQUIRED.
   All licensees under the provisions of this chapter shall maintain a
telephone and shall provide someone to regularly answer all complaints made and
to properly dispose of the same.
(Ord. 104, adopted 4-13-1945)
Sec. 28-17. JUDGMENTS AGAINST CITY BY REASON OF LICENSE GRANTED.
   Any licensee under this chapter shall pay any judgment which may be obtained
against the city, either alone or jointly with the licensee, on account of any
injury or damage to person or to property by reason of any license granted
hereunder and the licensee shall intervene and defend any suit or action, upon
written notice hereof given by the City Clerk.
(Ord. 104, adopted 4-13-1945)
Sec. 28-18. GARBAGE DISPOSAL DUMP.
   A.   Whenever any garbage is dumped or disposed of upon any premises or
place in the city which has been designated or approved for the purpose by the
City Health Officer, it shall be covered to a depth of one foot of clean earth
at the end of each day’s dumping where the garbage is below the finished grade.
No garbage shall be left uncovered for a period longer than 12 hours. When the
garbage is dumped or disposed of at the finished grade, it shall be covered
with at least three feet of clean earth. Whenever any licensee shall have
sufficient garbage to dump or dispose of in the manner above specified so that
it requires mechanical equipment to adequately cover to the depths above
specified, he or she shall provide himself or herself with adequate and proper
mechanical equipment so that the covering of the garbage may be properly done
in the time specified above. All equipment shall be approved by the City Health
Officer as to its fitness and adequacy to do the work required to comply
herewith.
   B.   It shall be the duty of any licensee operating any garbage disposal
dump as herein provided to so handle the same as to prevent fires and to
prevent loose material such as waste paper and similar matter from blowing away
and to operate the dump in a manner as not to permit the collection of loose,
unsightly waste or debris and to prevent odors and fumes from escaping
therefrom and to operate the dump in a manner as not to be deleterious to
public health, welfare and convenience of the neighborhood in which it is
located and in a manner as not to create a public or private nuisance. The
operation of the dump and manner of disposal of garbage at any dump operated by
any licensee hereunder shall at all times be under the general supervision and
direction of the City Health Officer and the licensee shall, at all times,
comply with all reasonable and proper directions of the Health Officer as to
the manner and method of operating of the dump and the handling of garbage.
(Ord. 104, adopted 4-13-1945)
Sec. 28-19. FEEDING TO LIVESTOCK.
   It shall be unlawful to feed any garbage to swine, poultry or other animals
within the limits of the city.
(Ord. 104, adopted 4-13-1945)
Sec. 28-20. COMPLAINTS; VIOLATIONS.
   A.   It shall be the duty of the Health Officer and the Police Chief to
enforce this section and to make investigation of all complaints or violation
of the terms and provisions hereof.
   B.   It shall also be the duty of all other officers and employees of the
city to report to the Health Officer or the Police Chief any and all violations
of this section that come to their attention or knowledge or as to which any
complaints are made of which they are informed.
(Ord. 104, adopted 4-13-1945)
Sec. 28-21. VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES.
   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter is responsible for a
municipal civil infraction, subject to payment of a civil fine of not less than
$500, plus costs and other sanctions, for each violation. Repeat offenses shall
be subject to increased fines as provided by code.
(Ord. 318, adopted 11-12-2001)
Sec. 28-22. LICENSE REVOCATION.
   Every license granted hereunder shall be revocable by the City Council, in
its discretion, with or without cause; and when any license shall be revoked
for noncompliance with the terms and conditions upon which it is granted or on
account of any violation of any section or regulation, the person holding the
license shall, in addition to all other penalties, forfeit all payments made
for the license.
(Ord. 104, adopted 4-13-1945)
Sec. 28-23. “GARBAGE” DEFINED.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definition shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   GARBAGE. Includes every refuse accumulation of animal, fruit or vegetable
matter that attends the preparation, use, cooking, dealing in or storing of
meats, fish, fowl, birds, fruit or vegetables; it shall also be held to include
kitchen and table refuse or waste matter of any nature or kind, mixed, handled
or included therewith.
(Ord. 104, adopted 4-13-1945)
CHAPTER 29: TREES
Section
   
29-1   Purpose and name
   
29-2   Definitions
   
29-3   Tree and shrub management
   
29-4   Builder responsibility
   
29-5   Protection of trees and shrubs
   
29-6   Compensation for trees damaged or destroyed
   
29-7   Authority of City Superintendent to inspect trees on private property
   
29-8   Private trees; disease, insect and other hazards
   
29-9   Trimming and removal of trees on private property
   
29-10   Violations and penalties
   
29-11   Enforcement and appeals
Sec. 29-1. PURPOSE AND NAME.
   The purpose of this chapter is to provide for the management and protection
of trees for the public health, safety and general welfare of the residents of
the city and to preserve and promote the city and its landscape resource
values. This chapter shall be known as the “Tree Chapter”.
(Ord. 101, adopted 5-10-1982; Ord. 201, adopted 5-10-1982)
Sec. 29-2. DEFINITIONS.
   A.   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
      BUILDER. All property owners who shall engage in new construction in any
zoning district of the city.
      CITY. The City of Plainwell, Michigan.
      CITY SUPERINTENDENT. The Superintendent of the Department of Public Works
or his or her authorized representative.
      COMMISSION. The City Parks and Tree Commission established by the city.
      CURB LAWN. The part of a street not covered by sidewalk or paving, lying
between the property line and the portion of the street paved for vehicular
traffic.
      DEPARTMENT. The Department of Public Works of the city.
      PARK. Includes all public parks having individual names and all areas,
whether owned by the city or not, to which the public has free access as a
park.
      PROHIBITED SPECIES. Any tree of poplar (Populus Sp.), willow (Salix Sp.),
box elder (Acer Negundo), silver maple (Acer Saccharinum), locust (Robina Sp.),
tree of heaven (Ailanthus Altissima), catalpa (Catalpa Sp.), mulberry (Morus
Sp.), Siberian elm (Ulmus pumila), birch (Betula Sp.) and any other species so
determined by the Commission.
      PRUNING. The proper trimming and/or cutting of limbs, branches and
leaves.
      PUBLIC UTILITY. Any person, owning or operating any pole, line, pipe or
conduit located in any public street or over or along any public easement or
right-of-way for the transmission of electricity, gas, telephone service or
telegraph service.
      STREET. All the land lying between property lines on either side of all
streets and highways and public rights-of-way in the city.
      TREE. Unless the context clearly indicates otherwise, means tree, shrubs,
bushes and all other woody vegetation.
      TREE TOPPING. The severe cutting back of tree limbs to stubs larger than
three inches in diameter within the crown of the tree to a degree so as to
remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. TREE TOPPING shall also
include stubbing, heading, heading-back, stubbing-off, hatracking, topping off,
dehorning, lopping and other similar practices.
   B.   The provisions of this chapter, except as otherwise specifically stated
herein, shall apply only to public streets, parkways, parks and other land
publicly owned or controlled by the city.
(Ord. 101, adopted 5-10-1982; Ord. 264, eff. 12-16-1990)
Sec. 29-3. TREE AND SHRUB MANAGEMENT.
   The planting, maintenance, pruning or removal of trees in places open to the
public in the city shall be done by the Department by order of the
Superintendent upon recommendation of the Commission. The action may be
initiated by the Commission, City Superintendent, City Manager, City Council or
by petition of parties owning a majority of the lineal footage on the fronting
property along a street.
   A.   No person shall hereafter plant, transplant, prune or remove any tree
on any street, street lawn, park or public place in the city, nor cause the act
to be done by others without first obtaining a written permit from the office
of the City Clerk. Application for permits must be made not less than 72 hours
in advance of the time the work is intended to commence and each permit granted
shall contain an expiration date not to exceed 60 days from the date of
issuance.
   B.   Each permit issued by the City Clerk shall describe the work to be
done, the number of trees to be removed or planted and the location, size,
species or variety of each tree, the method of planting and other information
that the City Superintendent may require to ensure that the work will be done
properly. Any permit issued will be void if its terms are violated. Whenever
any tree shall be planted in conflict with the provisions of the permit, it
shall be lawful for the Superintendent to cause removal of the same and the
cost for the removal shall be assessed to the permittee as provided by law in
the case of special assessments or as otherwise provided herein.
   C.   The City Superintendent shall promulgate rules for the proper pruning
techniques to be used on trees located on public property or publicly
maintained rights-of-way. The rules and any modifications to the rules, shall
be subject to approval by resolution of the City Council. A copy of the rules
shall be kept on file by the City Clerk for public inspection.
(Ord. 101, adopted 5-10-1982)
Sec. 29-4. BUILDER RESPONSIBILITY.
   A.   General. Builders shall be required to fulfill tree planting and
protection requirements as provided under the ordinances and policies of the
city and its City Parks and Tree Commission including, but not limited to,
subdivision regulations and site plan requirements.
   B.   Minimum planting requirements. One street tree of an approved species
measuring at least one and one-half inch caliper shall be planted on all new
construction sites, residential or otherwise, for each site or lot of 75 feet
or less and at least two trees for every lot in excess of 75 feet frontage.
Corner lots shall require at least one tree for each street. The builder shall
be responsible for fulfilling these requirements.
(Ord. 101, adopted 5-10-1982)
Sec. 29-5. PROTECTION OF TREES AND SHRUBS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to do any of the
following acts in any tree lawn, park, publicly maintained right-of-way or
other public place:
   A.   Fasten any sign, card, poster, wire, rope or other material to, around
or through, any tree or shrub or its guard, except in emergencies such as
storms or accidents;
   B.   Remove, break, injure, mutilate, kill, cut, peel or destroy any tree or
shrub by any means or in any manner;
   C.   Permit any fire to burn where the fire will injure any portion of any
tree or shrub;
   D.   Permit any toxic chemical to seep, drain or to be emptied on or about
any tree or shrub;
   E.   Deposit, store, place or maintain, on any street, highway or other
public place, any brick, sand, stone, concrete or other material which may
impede free passage of water, air and fertilizer to the roots of any tree or
shrub growing therein;
   F.   Fail to repair or stop any leak existing or occurring in any gas pipe
or main within a radius of 40 feet of any tree;
   G.   Knowingly permit any electrical wires to come into contact with any
tree or shrub;
   H.   Allow excavations and driveways to be placed within five feet of any
tree without written permit from the Superintendent. Any person making the
excavation or construction shall guard any tree within six feet thereof with a
good substantial frame box to be approved by the Department and all building
materials or other debris shall be kept at least four feet from any tree;
   I.   Plant any prohibited species of tree as hereinafter provided herein.
Exceptions to this prohibition may be granted by the City Council upon
recommendation of the Commission after review on a case by case basis; and/or
   J.   Allow the practice of tree topping or any other prohibited pruning
technique prescribed. Exceptions to this prohibition may be granted by the City
Council upon recommendations by the Commission after review on a case by case
basis for trees severely damaged by storms or other natural or accidental
causes or if permitted pruning practices are impractical due to location of a
tree under utility wires or because of some other obstruction.
(Ord. 101, adopted 5-10-1982)
Sec. 29-6. COMPENSATION FOR TREES DAMAGED OR DESTROYED.
   Any tree growing on any street, curb tree lawn, park or other public place
which is destroyed or damaged to the point where repair or replacement is
needed shall be the responsibility of the party responsible for the damage or
destruction in an amount necessary to replace or repair the destroyed or
damaged trees.
(Ord. 101, adopted 5-10-1982)
Sec. 29-7. AUTHORITY OF CITY SUPERINTENDENT TO INSPECT TREES ON PRIVATE
PROPERTY.
   The Superintendent shall have authority to enter upon private property at
all reasonable hours for purposes of examining any trees, shrubs, plants or
vines where hazardous conditions, destructive insects or diseases are
suspected. The Superintendent may remove the specimens as required for analysis
to determine the presence of insect, disease or other detrimental conditions.
It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent the Superintendent or agents
from entering private property for purposes of carrying out his or her duties
hereunder.
