(Ord. 101, adopted 5-10-1982)
Sec. 29-8. PRIVATE TREES; DISEASE, INSECT AND OTHER HAZARDS.
   A.   When the City Superintendent shall discover that any tree growing on
private property within the city is afflicted with any dangerous insect,
infestation, disease or condition, he or she shall immediately serve a written
notice upon the property owner or his or her agent describing the tree or
trees, their location, the nature of the insect infestation, disease or
condition and ordering the owner or his or her agent to take necessary measures
to abate the insect infestation or disease or condition, to prevent the
spreading thereof and specifying the corrective measures required to be taken.
This notice may require the pruning, treatment or destruction of the affected
trees as reasonably necessary.
   B.   Every notice shall be complied with within a definite time as stated in
the notice, but not less than ten days after service thereof upon the property
owner.
   C.   If, at the expiration of the time limit in the notice, the owner has
not complied with the requirements thereof, the Superintendent shall carry out
the requirements of that notice. The cost of completing the work necessary to
resolve the condition complained of shall be assessed against the property on
the next general assessment roll of the city.
(Ord. 101, adopted 5-10-1982)
Sec. 29-9. TRIMMING AND REMOVAL OF TREES ON PRIVATE PROPERTY.
   A.   Any tree growing on private property and so located as to extend its
branches over a public street, highway, sidewalk, park or other public place or
so located as to become a traffic hazard shall be trimmed or removed by the
property owner on whose property the tree stands, so as to remove the
obstruction from the public street, highway, sidewalk, park or public place and
so as to eliminate the traffic hazard and the menace and the danger to the
public, pursuant to written notice by and under the supervision of the
Superintendent.
   B.   When the notice is given, the property owner will be given a reasonable
and definite time to comply with the order, but not less than ten days.
   C.   If the work is not satisfactorily completed within that time, then the
Superintendent may enter upon the property, make the necessary trimming or
removals and properly dispose of the same; provided that, all or part of the
costs involved in the trimming or removal when done by the Superintendent shall
be assessed against the property on the next general assessment roll of the
city.
   D.   The city shall have the right to trim any tree or shrub on private
property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street
from a street light.
(Ord. 101, adopted 5-10-1982)
Sec. 29-10. VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES.
   A.   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter is responsible
for a municipal civil infraction, subject to payment of a civil fine of not
less than $500, plus costs and other sanctions, for each violation. Repeat
offenses shall be subject to increased fines as provided by code.
   B.   Imposition of a penalty for a violation of this chapter shall not be
construed as a waiver the city’s right to collect from a violator the costs of
the tree work done by the city which the violator was required to pay, but
failed to pay, under the provisions of this chapter or the right of the city to
collect from the violator the value of any tree illegally damaged or destroyed.
   C.   The city retains the right to seek and obtain injunctive relief in
addition to or as an alternative to the penalties described above in order to
promote the purposes of this chapter.
   D.   Each tree for which there is a violation of the provisions of this
chapter shall constitute a separate violation.
(Ord. 318, adopted 11-12-2001)
Sec. 29-11. ENFORCEMENT AND APPEALS.
   The City Superintendent is designated as the enforcing agency to see that
the provisions of this chapter are obeyed and all complaints as to the
violation of this chapter shall be presented in writing to the City Attorney
and shall be prosecuted in the name of the city. If, at any time, a dispute
arises or shall exist relative to or under the provisions of this chapter, the
dispute shall first be submitted to the Commission for review and
recommendation.
(Ord. 101, adopted 5-10-1982)
CHAPTER 30: YARD WASTE
Section
Article I. Yard Waste
   
30-1   Title, purpose and definitions
   
30-2   Depositing yard wastes upon public or private property
   
30-3   Lots under development
   
30-4   Biodegradable bags
   
30-5   Rules for collection of yard wastes
   
30-6   Loose leaf pick up
   
30-7   Emergency provisions
   
30-8   Violations and penalties
Article II: Waste Management Project
   
30-9   Purpose
   
30-10   Definitions
   
30-11   Citywide residential curbside recycling and semi-annual trash
collection established
   
30-12   Scope of service exceptions
   
30-13   Residential recycling and semi-annual trash collection
   
30-14   Acceptable materials for collection
   
30-15   Waste collection schedule
   
30-16   Recycling of recyclables/disposal of trash
   
30-17   Rates, charges and cost recovery fees
   
30-18   Accumulation of recyclables or trash
   
30-19   Utilization of service conditions
   
30-20   Scattered or unacceptable refuse responsibility
   
30-21   Schedule of collections
   
30-22   Holidays
   
30-23   Penalty
ARTICLE I. YARD WASTE
Sec. 30-1. TITLE, PURPOSE AND DEFINITIONS.
   A.   Title. This chapter may be referred to as the “Yard Waste Chapter” and
may be cited as such and referred herein as “this chapter”.
   B.   Purpose. The purpose of this chapter is to provide for the collection
and disposal of yard wastes in a manner which protects the health, safety and
general welfare of the residents of the city.
   C.   Definitions. For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions
shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different
meaning.
      BIODEGRADABLE. Capable of being broken down by naturally occurring
organisms.
      COMPOST. A mixture that consists largely of decaying organic matter used
for fertilizer and soil conditioning.
      YARD WASTES. Grass clippings, weeds, leaves, trees and shrubs or parts
thereof and garden residue.
(Ord. 259, adopted 4-9-1990)
Sec. 30-2. DEPOSITING YARD WASTES UPON PUBLIC OR PRIVATE PROPERTY.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to place or deposit or cause to be
placed or deposited upon public or private property within the city or in any
area under the jurisdiction of the city, any yard wastes except as provided by
this chapter. This section shall not apply to yard waste which is part of a
properly maintained compost pile or program.
(Ord. 259, adopted 4-9-1990)
Sec. 30-3. LOTS UNDER DEVELOPMENT.
   It is not the intent of this chapter to provide for pick up of yard wastes
from lots being cleared for development. When authorized by the City Council,
pickup of wastes from the lots shall be done on a time and material basis.
(Ord. 259, adopted 4-9-1990)
Sec. 30-4. BIODEGRADABLE BAGS.
   Grass clippings, weeds, leaves and garden residue will only be collected in
biodegradable bags placed in the curb lawn area or, where there is no curb,
adjacent to the asphalt street. It shall be a violation of this chapter for any
unauthorized person to print or cause to be printed bags marked “City of
Plainwell Composting Program”. The “Rules for Collection of Yard Wastes” shall
establish cost and distribution points for bags.
(Ord. 259, adopted 4-9-1990)
Sec. 30-5. RULES FOR COLLECTION OF YARD WASTES.
   The “Rules for Collection of Yard Wastes”, as promulgated by the city, shall
establish the dates for pickup. No person shall set out for pick up or cause to
be set out for pick up, any yard wastes prior to 5:00 p.m. on Friday
immediately prior to the established pick up date. Any yard waste set out
subsequent to pick up shall be removed from the curb lawn area within 48 hours.
(Ord. 259, adopted 4-9-1990)
Sec. 30-6. LOOSE LEAF PICK UP.
   Rules for the pick up of loose leaves will be provided for in the “Rules for
Collection of Yard Wastes”.
(Ord. 259, adopted 4-9-1990)
Sec. 30-7. EMERGENCY PROVISIONS.
   Upon consultation with the Mayor, the City Manager is authorized to suspend
the provisions of this chapter in the event of an emergency resulting from
natural disasters such as wind and ice storms.
(Ord. 259, adopted 4-9-1990)
Sec. 30-8. VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES.
   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter is responsible for a
municipal civil infraction, subject to payment of a civil fine of not less than
$250, plus costs and other sanctions, for each violation. Repeat offenses shall
be subject to increased fines as provided by code, except that the increased
fine for a repeat offense shall be as follows.
   A.   The fine for any offense which is a first repeat offense shall be not
less than $500, plus costs and other sanctions.
   B.   The fine for any offense which is a second repeat offense or any
subsequent repeat offense shall be not less than $1,000, plus costs and other
sanctions.
(Ord. 318, adopted 11-12-2001)
ARTICLE II: WASTE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM
Sec. 30-9. PURPOSE.
   Sections
30-9 through
30-23 are to establish a waste management project in the city and to regulate
the monthly collection, transportation and recycling of recyclables, as defined
in these sections and the semi-annual collection, transportation and disposal
of trash, as defined in this chapter, generated by residential units and to
authorize the charging of fees for the services. These sections are enacted
pursuant to Public Act 451 of 1994, as amended. The City Council finds that the
establishment of a waste management project and monthly residential recycling
and semi-annual trash collection and related requirements pursuant to this
chapter shall promote the public health, safety and welfare by conserving
natural resources and by preventing the discard of trash, as defined in this
chapter, except by proven waste disposal means and methods.
(Ord. 339, adopted 6-13-2005)
Sec. 30-10. DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BULKY WASTE. Stoves, refrigerators, water tanks, washing machines, furniture
and other similar waste materials generated by a producer, but not including
construction debris, dead animals, hazardous waste or stable matter.
Refrigeration units must have Freon removed by a certified technician,
indicated by a sticker, prior to collection. Except for the items specifically
listed, an item of BULKY WASTE may not weigh more than 60 pounds.
   CITY. The City of Plainwell, Michigan.
   COMPOSTABLES. Common yard waste, such as lawn clippings, leaves, grass,
flower stems, bush clippings.
   CONSTRUCTION DEBRIS. Waste building materials resulting from construction,
remodeling, repair or demolition operations.
   CONTRACTOR. The person, corporation or partnership performing refuse
collection and disposal and recycling under contract with the city.
   DISPOSAL SITE. A refuse depository including, but not limited to, sanitary
landfills, transfer stations, incinerators and waste processing/separation
centers licensed, permitted or approved by all governmental bodies and agencies
having jurisdiction and requiring the licenses, permits or approvals to receive
refuse for processing or final disposal.
   GARBAGE. All putrescible or easily decomposable animal or vegetable waste
matter and normal household garbage generated by a producer.
   PRODUCER. An owner, lessee or occupant of a unit who may generate garbage,
trash, bulky waste, compostables, stable matter and recyclables.
   RECYCLABLES. Newsprint, glass bottles and jars, #1 and #2 plastics, steel
and tin cans and magazines. Additional items may be added as agreed to by the
city and the contractor.
   STABLE MATTER. All manure and other waste matter normally accumulated in or
about a stable or any animal, livestock or poultry enclosure and resulting from
the keeping of animals, poultry or livestock.
   TRASH. All sawdust, printed matter, paper, pasteboard, rags, straw, used and
discarded mattresses, used and discarded clothing, used and discarded shoes and
boots, combustible waste pulp and other products such as are used for
packaging, crockery, glass, ashes, cinders, floor sweepings, mineral or
metallic substances and any and other similar waste materials generated by a
producer. TRASH also includes bulky waste, but does not include construction
debris, compostables, dead animals, hazardous waste, garbage, recyclables or
stable matter.
   UNIT. A dwelling or business within the corporate limits of the city. A UNIT
shall be deemed occupied when either water or light and power services are
being supplied thereto. A condominium dwelling, whether of single- or multi-
level construction and rental apartments shall each be considered a UNIT.
(Ord. 339, adopted 6-13-2005)
Sec. 30-11. CITYWIDE RESIDENTIAL CURBSIDE RECYCLING AND SEMI-ANNUAL TRASH
COLLECTION ESTABLISHED.
   A.   The city shall collect recyclables from the curbside on a monthly basis
and shall collect trash from the curbside on a semi-annual basis.
   B.   The services may be made under the provisions of a contract with a duly
licensed contractor.
(Ord. 339, adopted 6-13-2005)
Sec. 30-12. SCOPE OF SERVICE EXCEPTIONS.
   Monthly curbside recycling and semi-annual curbside trash collection shall
be provided by the city to owners, lessees and occupants of residential units.
These services may also be provided to those owning, leasing or occupying
commercial and industrial units who request the services.
(Ord. 339, adopted 6-13-2005)
Sec. 30-13. RESIDENTIAL RECYCLING AND SEMI-ANNUAL TRASH COLLECTION.
   A.   All persons who are owners, lessees or occupants of a residential unit
shall participate in the monthly curbside recycling and semi-annual curbside
trash collection program established by this chapter.
   B.   Owners, lessees or occupants of commercial and industrial units may
participate in the monthly curbside recycling and semi-annual curbside trash
collection program established by this chapter by request.
(Ord. 339, adopted 6-13-2005)
Sec. 30-14. ACCEPTABLE MATERIALS FOR COLLECTION.
   Only recyclables and trash as those terms are defined in this chapter shall
be collected by the city for purposes of this chapter.
(Ord. 339, adopted 6-13-2005)
Sec. 30-15. WASTE COLLECTION SCHEDULE.
   The city shall provide for a systematic recyclable and trash collection and
disposal system, which shall provide for the collection of recyclables from
suitable curbside locations at least once each month and shall provide for the
collection of trash from suitable curbside locations at least semi-annually.
(Ord. 339, adopted 6-13-2005)
Sec. 30-16. RECYCLING OF RECYCLABLES/DISPOSAL OF TRASH.
   All recyclables and trash collected by the city shall be properly deposited
at a disposal site approved for the purposes by the state.
(Ord. 339, adopted 6-13-2005)
Sec. 30-17. RATES, CHARGES AND COST RECOVERY FEES.
   A.    The rates, including late fees, to be charged for the collection of
recyclables and trash shall be established from time to time by resolution of
the City Council. A fee shall be charged for the services and the charges shall
be made against each lot, parcel or premises to which recyclable and trash
collection services are supplied by the city and the fee shall be paid to the
city by the owners, lessees or occupants thereof.
   B.    No free service shall be allowed for any user of the recyclable and
trash collection system.
   C.    The city may charge a late fee to owners, lessees or occupants of any
unit for failure to make timely payment of the charges for recycling and trash
collection.
   D.    If payment for recyclable and trash collection service is not made
within 90 days of the due date specified on the bill, a notice may be sent by
first class mail that service may be discontinued. The city may discontinue
service from the premises against which the lien created by this chapter has
accrued if a person fails to pay the charges or the city may institute a civil
action for the collection of the same against the owners, lessees or occupants
of the premises. The city’s attempt to collect these charges by civil process
shall not invalidate or waive any lien upon the premises.
   E.    The city shall have, as security for payment of recyclable and trash
collection service charges, for charges to any customer, a lien upon the real
estate to which the service was supplied. The lien shall become effective
immediately upon billing for the service to the real estate.
   F.   The lien may be enforced by the general laws of the state providing for
the enforcement of tax liens. The lien created by this chapter shall have
priority over all other liens, except taxes or special assessments and shall
have equal priority with other liens imposed for city supplied municipal
services.
(Ord. 339, adopted 6-13-2005)
Sec. 30-18. ACCUMULATION OF RECYCLABLES OR TRASH.
   The owner, lessee or occupant of any unit shall not permit the accumulation
of recyclables upon any premises under his or her control for a period of more
than 30 days and shall not permit the accumulation of trash upon any premises
under his or her control for a period of more than six months.
(Ord. 339, adopted 6-13-2005)
Sec. 30-19. UTILIZATION OF SERVICE CONDITIONS.
   The owner, lessee or occupant of any unit participating in the recyclable
collection service shall place accumulated recyclables in containers, bags,
bins and bundles approved by the city or contractor. The containers, bags, bins
and bundles shall be placed by the owner, lessee or occupant of the unit at
curbside (that portion of the right-of-way adjacent to paved or traveled city
roadways, including alleys) in front of the unit no more than one day prior to
the scheduled collection date and no later than 7:00 a.m. on the day of
collection. Containers, bags, bins and bundles shall be placed as close to the
roadway as practicable without interfering with or endangering the movement of
vehicles or pedestrians. Trash shall be set five feet from recycling bins and
all other items shall be set an additional five feet from trash. The
containers, bags, bins and bundles intended for collection shall not be broken.
Any user of this service shall not place or cause to be placed at curbside for
city collection and disposal any unacceptable materials for collection.
(Ord. 339, adopted 6-13-2005)
Sec. 30-20. SCATTERED OR UNACCEPTABLE REFUSE RESPONSIBILITY.
   The owner, lessee or occupant of a unit shall clean up and remove from the
curbside and premises any scattered recyclable and trash resulting from the
breakage or opening of any container, bag, bin or bundle within 24 hours after
the same has been scattered. Any container, bag, bin or bundle contents not
accepted for collection shall be removed from the curbside within 24 hours of
the regularly scheduled collection day.
(Ord. 339, adopted 6-13-2005)
Sec. 30-21. SCHEDULE OF COLLECTIONS.
   The schedule of routes and days for the monthly recyclable collection
service and the semi-annual trash collection created by this chapter shall be
determined by the city.
(Ord. 339, adopted 6-13-2005)
Sec. 30-22. HOLIDAYS.
   Recyclable and trash collections shall not be made on the following
holidays: January 1 (New Year’s Day); the last Monday in May (Memorial Day or
Decoration Day); July 4 (Independence Day); the first Monday in September
(Labor Day); the fourth Thursday of November (Thanksgiving Day); and December
25 (Christmas Day). Whenever collections are interrupted because of one of
these holidays, the collection of recyclables or trash shall be postponed one
day. All regularly scheduled Friday collections interrupted by one of the
foregoing holidays shall be made on Saturday of the same week.
(Ord. 339, adopted 6-13-2005)
Sec. 30-23. PENALTY.
   A.   Any person who violates any of the applicable provisions of this
chapter shall be guilty of a municipal civil infraction which is punishable by
a fine of $500, plus court costs for each offense.
   B.   Each day a violation continues shall constitute a separate offense.
Increased civil fines may be imposed for repeat violations.
(Ord. 339, adopted 6-13-2005)
CHAPTER 31: BURNING
Section
Article I. Trash and Garbage
   
31-1   Purpose
   
31-2   Definitions
   
31-3   Open burning prohibited
   
31-4   Exceptions to open burning prohibitions
   
31-5   Open burning; general regulations
   
31-6   Incinerators; required to burn trash or garbage
   
31-7   Violations and penalties
Article II. Materials
   
31-8   Burning of materials
   
31-9   Outdoor wood burners
ARTICLE I. TRASH AND GARBAGE
Sec. 31-1. PURPOSE.
   This article is intended to regulate open burning and the burning of trash
or garbage within the city.
(Ord. 289, adopted 7-25-1994)
Sec. 31-2. DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   GARBAGE. Solid waste resulting from the processing, handling, preparation,
sale or consumption of food.
   INCINERATOR. Any equipment or device designed and used for the purpose of
destroying or disposing of garbage or trash by fire.
   OPEN BURNING. A fire from which the products of combustion are emitted
directly into the air without passing through a stack or chimney.
   PERSON. Includes any individual, partnership, firm, corporation or other
legal entity.
   TRASH. All waste material other than garbage, including, but not limited to,
yard trimmings such as grass, leaves, twigs, branches, brush, logs, stumps or
other natural refuse; building demolition debris and excess construction
materials; and automobiles, tires, rubber, plastics or other similar materials.
(Ord. 289, adopted 7-25-1994)
Sec. 31-3. OPEN BURNING PROHIBITED.
   Except as expressly provided, no person shall start or maintain any open
burning within the city, nor shall any person cause or permit open burning to
occur upon any premises owned or occupied by the person or under the person’s
control.
(Ord. 289, adopted 7-25-1994)
Sec. 31-4. EXCEPTIONS TO OPEN BURNING PROHIBITIONS.
   The following fires are permitted within the city, subject to the general
regulations for the permitted open burning:
   A.   Fires for outdoor cooking. The burning of wood, charcoal, propane or
other accepted fuel for the preparation of food in any form, in an approved
container or utensil manufactured for that purpose, when used in accordance
with accepted safety standards;
   B.   Fires for building and construction operations. The use of an approved
gaseous or liquid-fired salamander commonly employed in conjunction with
building and construction operations, when used in accordance with accepted
safety standards;
   C.   Fires for roofers, tinners and plumbers. Roofers, tinners, plumbers or
other mechanics pursuing a business requiring the use of fire(s) for the
purpose of heating tar, pitch or other materials used in the regular course of
an appropriate business or trade, while being used in accordance to acceptable
safety standards and conforming to all other applicable codes;
   D.   Fires for training public safety personnel. Open burning for the
specific purpose of training of public safety personnel in fire suppression
techniques; provided:
      1.   The area is adequately protected by public safety personnel and/or
trainees;
      2.   The fire is of short duration;
      3.   The atmosphere is relatively free of pollutants; and
      4.   The burning is conducted in accordance with other applicable local,
state and federal laws and regulations.
   E.   Campfires. A campfire in which dried wood, trees, branches, kindling,
wood chips, compressed wood or any other wood products are burned shall be
allowed; provided:
      1.   The campfire is in an approved container; and the approved container
is made of non-combustible materials, rocks, cement, or metal and is no more
than four feet in diameter (48 inches); and
      2.   The property owner on which the campfire is located has expressly
authorized the campfire in writing or is in attendance.
(Ord. 289, adopted 7-25-1994)
Sec. 31-5. OPEN BURNING; GENERAL REGULATIONS.
   The following regulations shall apply to all open burning permitted by § 
31-4.
   A.   Open burning shall be supervised and kept under control by a competent
adult (of at least 18 years of age) who shall be present at the site of the
fire at all times and until the fire is completely extinguished without
smoldering.
   B.   Adequate fire extinguishing equipment shall be readily available at the
site of the fire.
   C.   Open burning shall not be permitted within 50 feet from any building or
overhead wires.
   D.   Open burning shall not be permitted in any public street, right-of-way,
easement, alley or other public ground.
   E.   No open burning of any garbage or trash shall be permitted.
   F.   No open burning shall be permitted in barrels or other containers for
burning.
   G.   No open burning shall be permitted between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and
7:00 a.m. of the following morning.
   H.   Materials to be burned must be dry and readily combustible.
   I.   The Fire Chief (or an authorized representative) may order any person
to refrain from starting or if started, to extinguish, any open burning which
is otherwise permitted by this chapter, if, in the Fire Chief’s opinion, the
open burning would be unsafe due to the particular circumstances, including,
but not limited to, unfavorable weather conditions or the size, duration, time
of day, location or manner of burning. It is a violation of this chapter for
any person to fail to comply with an order of the Fire Chief, as provided by
this section.
(Ord. 289, adopted 7-25-1994)
Sec. 31-6. INCINERATORS; REQUIRED TO BURN TRASH OR GARBAGE.
   No person shall destroy or dispose of any trash or garbage by fire within
the city, except within an incinerator which meets all of the following
requirements.
   A.   The combustion chamber of the incinerator must be completely enclosed
within a building and vented through a chimney or stack.
   B.   The incinerator must be designed, constructed and used so as to:
      1.   Prevent the emission of noxious odors;
      2.   Prevent the emission of smoke, fly ash, heat or other air
contaminants in unreasonable quantities or in a manner or to an extent that may
be detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of the community; and
      3.   Meet all applicable local, state or federal laws or regulations
including those of Article II herein.
(Ord. 289, adopted 7-25-1994)
Sec. 31-7. VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES.
   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter is responsible for a
municipal civil infraction, subject to payment of a civil fine of not less than
$250, plus costs and other sanctions, for each violation. Repeat offenses shall
be subject to increased fines as provided by code; except that, the increased
fine for a repeat offense shall be as follows.
   A.   The fine for any offense which is a first repeat offense shall be not
less than $500, plus costs and other sanctions.
   B.   The fine for any offense which is a second repeat offense or any
subsequent repeat offense shall be not less than $1,000, plus costs and other
sanctions.
(Ord. 318, adopted 11-12-2001)
ARTICLE II . MATERIALS
Sec. 31-8. BURNING OF MATERIALS.
   A.   Except as otherwise provided in this code, no person shall have, start,
use or contribute to any fire or knowingly allow a fire to continue with the
person’s consent or under the person’s supervision or direction or in any place
fully or partially possessed or controlled by that person if the fire is used
for the destruction of any thing or substance, including, but not limited to,
leaves, needles, brush, grass, paper, trash, garbage and refuse.
   B.   No person shall have, start, use or contribute to or allow to be
started, used or contributed to any fire outside of any premises, except for a
fire for cooking purposes burning only gas or charcoal which is entirely
contained in a grill or smoker designed and intended for use for cooking
purposes.
   C.   A violation of this section shall be a municipal civil infraction
punishable as provided in the city code.
Sec. 31-9. OUTDOOR WOOD BURNERS.
   A.   OUTDOOR WOOD BURNERS means any device, appliance, equipment, apparatus
or structure which:
      1.   Is designed, intended and/or used to provide hot water heat, hot
water or steam to any associated structure;
      2.   Operates by burning wood; and
      3.   Is not located within the structure to be heated.
   B.   All outdoor wood burners shall be installed to meet all of the
following requirements:
      1.   Be positioned at least 50 feet from each lot line;
      2.   Be positioned at least 100 feet from the primary structure on each
adjacent lot;
      3.   Be placed in the rear yard, as defined in the city’s zoning
ordinance;
      4.   Be installed by a licensed contractor, according to a mechanical
permit; and
      5.   Be installed with an exhaust stack at least as high as the highest
chimney of the primary structure on the lot on which it is placed or on an
adjacent lot.
   C.   No outdoor wood burner shall be installed, put to use or remain in use
without first obtaining a permit from the City Manager designee after
furnishing the following information:
      1.   A drawing providing and identifying all of the information necessary
to assure compliance with this section;
      2.   Manufacturer’s specifications for the outdoor wood burner; and
      3.   Proof of compliance with all applicable state and federal statutes,
rules, regulations and permit requirements, including, without limitation, all
applicable building and construction codes, fire codes and the zoning
ordinance.
   D.   An area around an outdoor wood burner shall be free of vegetation or
other combustible materials according to the greater distance of the
manufacturers’ specifications and recommendations or ten feet.
   E.   No fuel other than dry, natural hard wood, without additive, may be
burned in an outdoor wood burner.
   F.   Outdoor wood burners and associated installations shall be subject to
inspection by the city’s Zoning Administrator and Mechanical Inspector at any
reasonable time to assure compliance with this section. Inspection by the
Mechanical Inspector shall be required before any wood burner is put into
service.
   G.   Nothing contained here shall authorize any installation that is a
public or private nuisance, regardless of compliance with this section. This
chapter shall not be a defense to any civil claims for nuisance or for any
other cause.
   H.   To the extent that this section conflicts with the provisions of the
zoning chapter the provisions of this section shall control.
   I.   A violation of this section shall be a municipal civil infraction
punishable as provided in the city code.
CHAPTER 32: FALSE ALARM
Section
   
32-1   Title; definitions
   
32-2   False alarms
   
32-3   Appeals
Sec. 32-1. TITLE; DEFINITIONS.
   A.   Title. This chapter shall be known as the “False Alarm Chapter” and may
be cited as such and referred to herein as “this chapter”.
   B.   Definitions. For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions
shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different
meaning.
      ALARM SYSTEM. A device or assembly of equipment or devices designed or
arranged to signal the presence or existence of a hazard requiring urgent
attention of police or fire personnel. Those systems shall include, but not be
limited to, intrusion alarms, robbery alarms, fire alarms, medical emergency
alarms or other alarms requiring an emergency response by police or fire
personnel. ALARM SYSTEMS monitoring temperature and humidity and alarms which
do not require any police or fire personnel to respond are excluded from this
chapter.
      ALARM USER. Any person, whether owner, occupant or tenant, upon whose
premises an alarm system is maintained or operated within the city, except for
alarm systems on a motor vehicle. If, however, the alarm system on a motor
vehicle is connected with an alarm system at a premises, the person using a
system is an ALARM USER.
      FALSE ALARM. Activation of an alarm system, except caused by fire,
criminal activity or other lawful purpose for which the system is in operation.
Activation of an alarm system as a result of power failure, electrical storms
or other circumstances not under the control of the alarm system user shall not
be considered FALSE ALARMS under this definition.
      PERSON. Any individual, partnership, corporation, unincorporated
association or any group of persons.
(Ord. 254, adopted 5-22-1989)
Sec. 32-2. FALSE ALARMS.
   A.   No alarm user shall maintain, use or allow the use of an alarm system
or alarm systems which signal false alarms in excess of that permitted herein.
   B.   False alarm calls made unintentionally or unknowingly. As an exercise
of its enforcement discretion, the city may waive any fine or penalty for the
first two false alarm calls unintentionally or unknowingly sent or caused to be
sent by any person within one calendar year. However, except as provided by
division C. below for intentionally or knowingly sending a false alarm call,
any person who sends or causes to be sent three or more false alarm calls
within one calendar year is responsible for a municipal civil infraction,
subject to payment of a civil fine, as follows.
      1.   For the third false alarm call within a calendar year period: not
less than $250, plus costs and other sanctions, for each violation.
      2.   For the fourth false alarm call within a calendar year period: not
less than $500, plus costs and other sanctions, for each violation.
      3.   For the fifth and any subsequent false alarm call within a calendar
year period: not less than $1,000, plus costs and other sanctions, for each
violation.
   C.   False alarm calls made intentionally or knowingly. It shall be a
misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than $500 or imprisonment for not
more than 90 days or both the fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the
court, for any person to intentionally or knowingly send or cause to be sent, a
false alarm call.
   D.   This chapter shall not apply to the use of an alarm system by federal,
state or local law enforcement personnel.
(Ord. 254, adopted 5-22-1989; Ord. 318, passed 11-12-2001)
Sec. 32-3. APPEALS.
   Appeal of a service fee or other action taken under the provisions of this
chapter may be made to the City Manager.
(Ord. 254, adopted 5-22-1989)
CHAPTER 33: ENVIRONMENTAL CLEANUP AND COST RECOVERY
Section
   
33-1   Purpose
   
33-2   Definitions
   
33-3   Release of hazardous materials prohibited; presumption; public nuisance
   
33-4   Duty to remove
   
33-5   Failure to remove
   
33-6   Liability for cleanup cost recovery
   
33-7   Recovery of costs
   
33-8   Non-exclusive charge
   
33-9   City inspection; report
   
33-10   Violations and penalties
Sec. 33-1. PURPOSE.
   This chapter provides for the recovery by the city from responsible parties
of all costs incurred by the city in responding to a release of hazardous
materials to protect the public health, safety and welfare and the environment.
(Ord. 317, adopted 10-8-2001)
Sec. 33-2. DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CLEANUP ACTIONS. Includes all the actions and activities, whether conducted
on an emergency or more long-term basis, as necessary:
      1.   To respond to a release of hazardous materials at a site, including,
but not limited to, evaluation, remedial action, demolition, health assessments
or studies;
      2.   To contain, isolate, collect, analyze, treat, disperse, remove,
destroy and dispose of hazardous materials released (or threatened to be
released) at the site as necessary to restore the site to its condition prior
to the release; and
      3.   To otherwise prevent, minimize or mitigate injury to the public
health, safety or welfare or to the environment and natural resources.
   CLEANUP COSTS. All costs and expenses incurred by the city (or incurred on
behalf of the city by any person, agency or entity acting at the request or
direction of the city) related in any way to site cleanup actions and
responding to a release or threatened release, including, but not limited to,
the actual labor and material costs of the city, such as employee wages, fringe
benefits, overtime, administrative overhead, standby costs, cost of equipment,
costs of equipment operation, costs of materials, costs of transportation,
costs of material disposal and costs of contracted labor, service charges and
interest, costs of retained experts and consultants, attorney’s fees,
litigation costs and any costs, charges, fines, penalties, sanctions imposed
against the city by any court or governmental entity. By way of further
example, cleanup costs also include, without limitation, the following:
      1.   The costs of providing firefighting, rescue services, medical
services, medical treatment, police services, mutual aid or any other public
safety services;
      2.   The costs of purchasing, renting, leasing, replacement,
decontamination, repair, destruction or disposal of all materials, equipment
and supplies used or obtained as necessary to respond to the release or to
clean up the site, including items such as disposable materials and supplies,
protective equipment, clothing, transportation, technical equipment, laboratory
equipment, medical supplies, fire suppression supplies and equipment, spill
control supplies and equipment;
      3.   The costs of any necessary cleanup actions at the site such as
diking, damming, trenching, covering, diverting, foaming, neutralizing,
isolating, burning, closing, plugging, moving, repairing, transferring,
recycling, monitoring, sampling and analysis;
      4.   The costs of any necessary evacuation, sheltering and feeding of
people, provision of alternative water supplies and other activities to protect
the public’s health and welfare and the environment; and
      5.   The costs of prosecuting any person in connection with the release,
including administrative costs relating thereto or to the production of
witnesses at any court proceedings, actual attorneys’ fees and all other
related legal expenses (including legal expenses incurred for efforts to
recover costs from responsible persons as provided by this chapter).
   DISPOSAL. The discharge, deposit, injection, dumping, spilling, leaking or
placing of any hazardous material into or on any land or water so that the
hazardous material of any constituent of the hazardous material may enter the
environment or be emitted into the air or discharged into any ground water or
surface water.
   ENVIRONMENT. Land, surface water, ground water, subsurface, strata, air,
fish, wildlife or biota within the city.
   HAZARDOUS MATERIAL. Any of the following:
      1.   Hazardous substances as defined in the Comprehensive Environmental
Response, Compensation and Liability Act of 1980, Pub. Law No. 96-510, 94
State, 2767, as amended; or as defined in Part 201 of Public Act 451 of 1994,
as amended; or as defined under other local, state or federal laws, rules or
regulations;
      2.   Hazardous waste as defined under 40 C.F.R. Part 261; or as defined
under Part 111 of Public Act 451 of 1994, as amended; or as defined under other
local, state or federal laws, rules or regulations;
      3.   Any material defined or listed as a toxic waste or pollutant in 40
C.F.R. § 401.15; in the Critical Materials Register promulgated by the State
Department of Environmental Quality: or under other local, state or federal
laws, rules or regulations;
      4.   Petroleum as described in Part 213 of Public Act 451 of 1994, as
amended;
      5.   Any substance or material in quantity or form which, in the
determination of the city, poses a substantial present or potential hazard to
human life, health and safety, welfare, property or the environment and shall
include, but shall not be limited to, such substances as chemicals, explosives,
oxidizers, peroxides, poisons, radioactive materials, petroleum or petroleum
products, gases, poisons, etiologic (biologic) agents, flammables and
corrosives; and
      6.   Any materials which have otherwise been declared hazardous by any
state or federal agency.
   RELEASE. Includes, but is not limited to, the accidental or intentional,
sudden or gradual, spilling, leaking, pumping, pouring, emitting, emptying,
discharging, injecting, escaping, leaching, dumping or disposing into the
environment or the abandonment or discarding of barrels, containers or other
receptacles containing a hazardous material.
   RESPONSIBLE PARTY.
      1.   Any person whose act or omission, whether intentional or
unintentional, causes or contributes to a release or threatened release;
      2.   The owner, operator, occupant or other person responsible for the
operation, maintenance or condition of any land, building, structure or vehicle
which was the situs or cause of the release or threatened release occurred;
      3.   Any person who owned, transported or had custody or control of the
hazardous material at the time of the release or threatened release; and
      4.   Any person who owned, transported or had custody or control of the
container which held the hazardous material at the time of or immediately prior
to the release or threatened release.
   SITE. Any area, place or property where hazardous materials have been
released, deposited, disposed of or otherwise come to be located.
   THREATENED RELEASE. Any circumstance that may reasonably be anticipated to
cause a release.
(Ord. 317, adopted 10-8-2001)
Sec. 33-3. RELEASE OF HAZARDOUS MATERIALS PROHIBITED; PRESUMPTION; PUBLIC
NUISANCE.
   A.   It shall be unlawful, whether intentional or unintentional and without
regard to negligence or fault, for any person to release hazardous material
into the environment in a quantity which is or may become injurious to the
public health, safety or welfare or the environment.
   B.   A release shall be presumed unlawful as provided by this chapter if the
level of hazardous materials released exceed the applicable cleanup criteria
for the site as provided by Part 201 of Public Act 451 of 1994, as amended.
   C.   Any prohibited release is declared a public nuisance subject to all
applicable remedies at law or in equity.
(Ord. 317, adopted 10-8-2001)
Sec. 33-4. DUTY TO REMOVE.
   It shall be the duty of any responsible party to immediately remove
hazardous materials released and to undertake and complete all necessary
cleanup actions at the site so as to ensure that the hazardous materials are
fully removed and the area is fully restored to its condition prior to the
release. At a minimum, the cleanup shall meet the conditions or standards
applicable to the site as established by the State Department of Environmental
Quality, pursuant to Part 201 of Public Act 451 of 1994, as amended or by other
applicable laws or regulations, if more restrictive than the conditions or
standards established pursuant to Part 201.
(Ord. 317, adopted 10-8-2001)
Sec. 33-5. FAILURE TO REMOVE.
   A.   Any responsible party who fails to fully comply with § 
33-4 shall be liable to the city, its agents, contractors and employees for any
cleanup costs incurred by the city, including, but not limited to, costs for
the removal and cleanup of any and all hazardous materials, restoration of the
site and responding to any threatened release.
   B.   If any responsible party fails to immediately remove hazardous material
released at a site, the city shall have the right to enter the property
involved with the release and remove and conduct a cleanup of all hazardous
materials, either by city employees or by contractors and agents of the city.
(Ord. 317, adopted 10-8-2001)
Sec. 33-6. LIABILITY FOR CLEANUP COST RECOVERY.
   All cleanup costs incurred by the city under § 
33-5 shall be the responsibility of the responsible parties. The responsible
parties shall fully repay and reimburse the city for all cleanup costs incurred
by the city. Liability shall only be imposed consistent with federal and state
laws.
(Ord. 317, adopted 10-8-2001)
Sec. 33-7. RECOVERY OF COSTS.
   A.   The city shall keep an itemized record of cleanup costs resulting from
a release or threatened release.
   B.   The total amount of costs to be reimbursed by a responsible party as
provided by this chapter shall be determined by the City Council, based upon
the record of costs kept by the city, information and recommendations received
from appropriate city personnel involved in responding to the release or
threatened release and other factors, circumstances and information as
determined appropriate by the City Council.
   C.   The city shall bill the responsible parties for all costs reimbursable
under this chapter. The bill shall require full payment within 45 days from the
date of mailing the bill by first class mail to the responsible party or within
other period for payment as determined appropriate by the City Council.
   D.   If cleanup costs are not paid by a responsible party, the city may take
whatever collection steps deemed appropriate by the city, including the
placement of all charges on the tax roll for the property and to levy and
collect the costs in the same manner as provided for the levy and collection of
real property taxes against the property.
   E.   Cleanup costs incurred by the city as provided by this chapter which
have not been paid by a responsible party shall constitute a lien against the
real property where the release occurred and may be levied as a tax upon the
property if the owner, operator or occupant of the property caused or
contributed to the release.
   F.   The city may pursue any other remedy or may institute any appropriate
action or proceedings in a court of competent jurisdiction to collect costs for
which liability is imposed under this chapter. All costs of any court action,
including actual attorney fees, shall also be a cleanup cost recoverable from a
responsible party as provided by this chapter.
   G.   The recovery of charges composed under this chapter does not limit or
modify the liability of any person under local, state or federal laws, rules or
regulations.
   H.   The remedies provided by this chapter shall be in addition to any other
remedies available at law or in equity and penalties as provided by law or
ordinance.
(Ord. 317, adopted 10-8-2001)
Sec. 33-8. NON-EXCLUSIVE CHARGE.
   A.   The reimbursable cleanup costs as provided for by this chapter shall be
in addition to and supplemental to the charges that may otherwise be made by
the city for the costs and expenses of maintaining a Department of Public
Safety.
   B.   Charges may additionally be collected by the city through general
taxation after a vote of the electorate approving the same or by a special
assessment established under the state statutes pertinent thereto. General Fund
appropriations may also be made to cover additional costs and expenses.
(Ord. 317, adopted 10-8-2001)
Sec. 33-9. CITY INSPECTION; REPORT.
   Authorized representatives of the city may, at any reasonable time, enter
and inspect any land, building or structure where hazardous materials are
stored, handled, processed, disposed of or treated, to ensure that there are no
significant or unreasonable present or potential risks to the public health,
safety or welfare or the environment, including persons using or occupying the
premises or persons using or occupying nearby or adjacent premises. A report
listing any violation of applicable laws, regulations and ordinances shall be
prepared by the city and kept on file. A copy of the report shall be provided
to the owner of the land, building or structure inspected.
(Ord. 317, adopted 10-8-2001)
Sec. 33-10. VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES.
   A person who violates any provision of this chapter is responsible for a
municipal civil infraction, subject to payment of a civil fine of not less than
$500, plus costs and other sanctions, for each violation. Repeat offenses shall
be subject to increased fines as provided by code.
(Ord. 317, adopted 10-8-2001)
CHAPTER 34: COST RECOVERY
Section
Article I. Hazardous Materials
   
34-1   Purpose
   
34-2   Definitions
   
34-3   Responsible parties
   
34-4   Response activity costs
   
34-5   Charges for services
   
34-6   Applicability of charges regardless of outcome
   
34-7   Additional remedies
   
34-8   Right to appeal
Article II. Assessable Charges
   
34-9   Purpose
   
34-10   Assessable services
   
34-11   Responsible parties
   
34-12   Charges for services
   
34-13   Payment for assessable services
ARTICLE I. HAZARDOUS MATERIALS
Sec. 34-1. PURPOSE.
   This article provides for the recovery by the city from responsible parties
of all costs incurred by the city in responding to a release or threatened
release of hazardous materials to protect the public health, safety and welfare
and the environment.
Sec. 34-2. DEFINITIONS.
   Other terms used in this article shall have the meanings provided in § 20101
of the State Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act, Public Act 451
of 1994, as amended, (NREPA), M.C.L.A. § 324.20101.
Sec. 34-3. RESPONSIBLE PARTIES.
   A.   The city shall bill all persons liable under the Natural Resource and
Environmental Protection Act, NREPA, Part 201 for “response activity costs” as
defined in this article and any or all transporters (as defined in NREPA Part
111) of any hazardous substance defined in NREPA § 20101, if a release or
threatened release occurs during transportation of that hazardous substance,
for response activity costs the city incurs due to any release or the
threatened release of hazardous substances. This article does not create or
affect any right of or restriction on the right of, the responsible party to
obtain any indemnification or contribution from the following parties, but only
creates rights for the city to collect from the parties.
      1.   Each owner and operator of a facility and each transporter shall be
jointly and severally liable for payment of the response activity costs
incurred by the city; and
      2.   Parents and/or guardians shall be responsible for payment for
response activity costs incurred by the city due to acts by minors who caused
the release.
   B.   A person otherwise liable under this section shall not be liable if
that person would have a defense to liability under NREPA Part 201.
Sec. 34-4. RESPONSE ACTIVITY COSTS.
   Response activity costs include all of those costs of a response activity as
provided in NREPA Part 201, specifically including, without limitation,
materials, equipment, manpower, administration and other costs incurred by the
City Public Safety Department or other departments; fees, rates and charges
paid to consultants, suppliers and contractors; costs resulting from injuries
or damage to people or property because of a release or a threatened release of
hazardous substances; and any other costs incurred by the city arising from or
related to any release or threatened release. Without limiting the generality
of the foregoing, the following are specific examples, but not an exclusive
list, of the costs:
   A.   Costs incurred to halt, abate, remediate or remedy any spill,
containment or release of any hazardous substances and any liabilities
resulting from the activity;
   B.   Costs incurred to extinguish or fight any fire in or at a structure or
on a property, including, but not limited to, overhauling equipment, fire
extinguishers and foam, any demolition costs if the structure must be
demolished to protect the public safety following the fire and any liabilities
resulting from such; and
   C.   Costs incurred to collect any amounts due under this article after the
first invoice.
Sec. 34-5. CHARGES FOR SERVICES.
   A.   The City Council may from time to time, by resolution, establish a
schedule of fees and charges in amounts reasonably determined to, on average,
recoup the costs of providing the response activities.
   B.   The City Council may, by resolution, establish fixed charges for
certain services instead of tracking the actual costs of the services.
Alternatively or for services for which no fixed fee is established, the city
may recover the actual costs incurred by the city.
   C.   Where one or more city department engages in response activities or
contracts for response activities in connection with an actual or threatened
release, costs incurred by city departments to do so shall be imposed upon
responsible parties, as follows:
      1.   An amount not less than $250 per hour or fraction thereof, for each
fire pumper required, in the opinion of the officer in command, to be utilized
in responding to the release;
      2.   An amount not less than $150 per hour or fraction thereof, for each
water tender utilized in responding to release;
      3.   An amount not less than $125 per hour or fraction thereof, for each
rescue vehicle utilized in responding to release;
      4.   An amount not less than $175 per hour or fraction thereof, for each
additional city owned department vehicle required, in the opinion of the
officer in command, to be utilized in responding to the release;
      5.   All personnel-related costs the city incurs as a result of
responding to the release. The costs may include, but are not limited to,
wages, salaries, benefits and insurance for city employees and overtime pay and
related fringe benefit costs for hourly employees. The personnel-related
charges shall begin after the first hour that the city department has responded
to the hazardous substances release and shall continue until all city
department personnel have concluded release-related responsibilities;
      6.   Other expenses the city incurs in responding to the release,
including, but not limited to, rental or purchase of machinery, equipment,
labor, consultants, legal and engineering fees and the replacement costs
related to disposable personal protective equipment, extinguishing agents,
supplies, water purchased from municipal water systems and meals refreshments
for personnel while responding to the hazardous substances release;
      7.   Charges to the city imposed by local, state or federal government
entities related to the hazardous substances release; and
      8.   Costs incurred in accounting for all hazardous material release-
related expenditures, including billing and collection costs.
   D.   All invoiced amounts shall be due and payable within 30 calendar days
of the date of the statement, unless an appeal is pending. Amounts not paid
when due shall bear interest at the rate of 1% per month or the highest
interest rate permitted by law, whichever is greater.
Sec 34-6. APPLICABILITY OF CHARGES REGARDLESS OF OUTCOME.
   The response activity under this article shall be applicable regardless of
the results or outcome of the activities with regard to the actual or
threatened hazardous substances release.
Sec. 34-7. ADDITIONAL REMEDIES.
   The response activity costs and charges specified by this article are
intended to reimburse the city for its reasonable costs and expenses incurred
and is not penal in nature. Accordingly, any responsible costs billed or
imposed pursuant to this article shall be in addition to any penal fines, fees
or other costs or expenses which may be imposed on the owner of operator of a
facility pursuant to any other law or ordinance.
Sec. 34-8. RIGHT TO APPEAL.
   Any person who receives a statement of costs assessed pursuant to this
article shall have the opportunity to appeal the costs to the City Manager. The
responsible party who wishes to appeal any assessable costs shall file a
written appeal with the City Manager within 14 calendar days of the date of the
statement of the billed costs stating why the costs are miscalculated or are
not assessable. The appeal will stay all payments due until the appeal is
decided by the City Manager. The City Manager shall make a determination
regarding the billed costs in the case appealed. The City Manager shall also
determine the date that any or all billed costs involved in the appeal will
become due.
ARTICLE II. ASSESSABLE CHARGES
Sec. 34-9. PURPOSE.
   A.   The purpose of this article is to authorize the Public Safety
Department to recover costs incurred in connection with certain assessable
services and to provide for the enforcement of this article.
   B.   This article provides for charges for certain assessable services,
defines responsibility for charges, clarifies that any party benefitting from
Public Safety Department services shall be liable for payment of services
rendered and allows the city to bill for other departments or agencies
providing assistance within the city.
Sec. 34-10. ASSESSABLE SERVICES.
   Costs associated with the following actions or services, also referred to as
“assessable services” in this section shall be jointly and severally assessed
to any and all responsible and benefitted parties. Costs incurred by the city
include, but are not limited to, materials, equipment, the wages and salaries
of city employees providing assessable services, all expenses of outside
sources or contractors, injuries or damage to people or property which results
from situations which cause the city to incur assessable costs, all costs
connected with the administration and provision of all chemical tests of blood,
breath or urine; all costs of equipment rental; all costs related to any
prosecution of the person causing the incident and any other factors deemed
relevant by the City Manager or Council. Assessable services also include:
   A.   Extraordinary cost incurred to extinguish or fight any fire in or at a
structure or on a property, including, but not limited to, overhauling
equipment, fire extinguishers and foam, any demolition cost if the structure
must be demolished to protect the public safety following the fire and any
liabilities resulting from such;
   B.   Cost incurred in connection with utility line (electrical power or
natural gas) or facility failure or problem and any liabilities resulting from
such;
   C.   Cost incurred in connection with any water rescue or recovery attempt
and liabilities resulting from such;
   D.   Cost incurred in connection with any technical rescue unit (i.e., the
equipment and/or specially trained rescue and/or recovery team provided by
governmental or private emergency response services to provide emergency
services in situations involving the technical rescue and/or recovery
situation) and any liabilities resulting from such;
   E.   Cost incurred in connection with a motor vehicle accident where one or
more persons were operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of an
alcoholic beverage or controlled substance or the combined influence of an
alcoholic beverage and a controlled substance;
   F.   Cost incurred in connection with the arrest or apprehension of any
person who, while under the influence of an alcoholic beverage or any
controlled substance or the combined influence of an alcoholic beverage and any
controlled substance, operates a motor vehicle when his or her physical or
mental abilities are impaired to a degree that he or she no longer has the
ability to operate a motor vehicle on any public roadway, street, right-of-way
or area open to the public; and
   G.   Costs associated with motor vehicle accident, extrication of individual
from a vehicle or motor vehicle fire, included, but not limited to, “spill
clean up” foam fire extinguishers and any liabilities resulting from such:
      1.   Costs associated with excessive request for emergency assistance,
including, but not limited to, calls made for a particular location or
commercial entity if that location or commercial entity has requested or
received emergency assistance of any type more than two times in the preceding
12 months;
      2.   Cost associated with a false alarm in excess of two times in a one
calendar year time period;
      3.   This article shall be construed to be responsibility and liability
of a civil nature and shall not be construed to conflict, contravene, enlarge
or reduce any criminal liability or responsibility, including fines imposed by
a court; and
      4.   Any assessable cost, including litigation expenses, which become
known to the city following the transmittal of a statement to the responsible
party pursuant to this article shall be billed in the same manner on a
subsequent statement to the responsible party.
Sec. 34-11. RESPONSIBLE PARTIES.
   A.   The city shall bill persons, entities or corporations determined to be
responsible for certain assessable services provided by or through the Public
Safety Department or other city departments.
   B.   Any party benefitting from the services shall be liable for payment of
the full charge for the services rendered. When a particular service rendered
by or through the Public Safety Department or other city department directly
benefits more than one person or property, the owner of each property so
benefitted and/or each person so benefitted, if property protection is not
involved, shall each be liable for the payment of the full charge for services.
Parents and/or guardians shall be responsible for payment for assessable
services incurred by minors who caused the condition or event leading to the
charges.
   C.   Any person who, while under the influence of an alcoholic beverage or
any controlled substance or the combined influence of an alcoholic beverage and
any controlled substance, operates a motor vehicle which results in assessable
services, as defined by this article, shall be liable for those assessable
services.
   D.   For purposes of this article, a person is under the influence of an
alcoholic beverage or controlled substance or the combined influence of an
alcoholic beverage or a controlled substance when his or her physical or mental
abilities are impaired to a degree that he or she no longer has the ability to
operate a motor vehicle with the caution characteristic of a sober person of
ordinary prudence. Further, it shall be presumed that a person was operating a
motor vehicle while under the influence of an alcoholic beverage if a chemical
analysis of his or her blood, urine or breath indicates that the amount of
alcohol in his or her blood rendered him or her impaired.
Sec. 34-12. CHARGES FOR SERVICES.
   The city establishes the following charges for services:
   A.   A flat rate fee of $250 for:
      1.   Spill clean up from motor vehicle accident or motor vehicle fire;
and/or
      2.   Personal injury accident.
   B.   Cost associated with city-owner apparatus when not covered by a flat
rate fee:
      1.   Staff vehicles: $50 per vehicle per hour;
      2.   Rescue vehicles: $125 per vehicle per hour;
      3.   Water rescue boat: $150 per vehicle per hour; or
      4.   Pumper, all types: $250 per vehicle per hour.
   C.   Recovery cost for staff and manpower when not covered by a flat fee:
      1.   Manpower: multiply number of people times their current wage; and
      2.   Recovery cost where flat rate fee is not associated will include all
additional cost from outside agencies, persons or equipment that are used to
halt, abate or remedy the situation as seen fit by the City Manager.
   D.   The City Council may, by a resolution, change these fees or add
additional fees.
Sec. 34-13. PAYMENT FOR ASSESSABLE SERVICES.
   A.   The Public Safety Director or his or her designee, may, within ten days
of receiving itemized costs or any part thereof, incurred for an assessable
services, submit a bill for these costs by first class mail or personal service
to the responsible parties as provided by this article. The bill(s) shall
require full payment in 30 days from the date of service.
   B.   Any failure by a responsible party to pay the bill for assessable
services within 30 days of service shall be considered in default. In case of
default, the city may commence a civil suit to recover the expenses and any
costs allowed by law.
   C.   This article shall be construed to be a responsibility and liability of
a civil nature and shall not be construed to conflict, contravene, enlarge or
reduce any criminal liability or responsibility, including fines imposed by a
court under the State Vehicle Code against a person for operating a motor
vehicle while under the influence of an alcoholic beverage and/or controlled
substance.
