as provided by Article IX of this chapter.
      3.   If an analysis of wastewater discharged from any user identifies any
strength characteristic in excess of normal strength domestic waste, then a
surcharge may be levied by the city against the user on any such excess
characteristic.
   C.   If any required meter fails, the meter shall be fixed or replaced at no
expense to the city by no more than 90 days from the date of the failure.
(Ord. 355, passed - -2010)
Sec. 35-141. RATES, CHARGES AND BILLING PROCEDURE.
   The amounts to be charged to users by the POTW under this chapter shall be
established from time-to-time by resolution of the City Council. All sums due
shall be billed according to a schedule established by resolution of the City
Council. If not paid within 15 days of due date, an additional charge equal to
10% of the total unpaid balance shall be added. Any delinquent bills with
penalties due the city (including any delinquent amounts determined to be
payable to the city under Sec. 4 of Article XI) shall be a lien against the
premises served and shall be spread on the next regular city tax roll. The lien
arising under this section shall be of the same effect as a lien created by
state and county taxes and collection shall be enforced in a like manner.
(Ord. 355, passed - -2010)
Sec. 35-142. USER CHARGE REVISIONS.
   A.   City to review. The City Council will review user wastewater
contributions, the total costs of operation and maintenance of the POTW, and
its user charge system, as provided by this section.
   B.   Purpose of review. The City Council will review and revise user charges
as determined necessary by the City Council to accomplish the following: (1)
maintain the proportionate distribution of operation and maintenance costs
among users and/or user classes; (2) generate sufficient revenue to pay the
total operation and maintenance costs necessary to the proper operation and
maintenance (including replacement) of the POTW; and (3) generate sufficient
revenue to pay for capital improvements and/or requirements of the POTW five-
year plan. The review process shall be conducted at least once every five
years.
   C.   User charge rates to be reviewed and amended. User charge rates shall
be reviewed and amended for the projected 12-month service period as determined
necessary by the City Council. Amendments to user charge rates shall be
determined following the applicable methodologies as established from time-to-
time by resolution of the City Council. If a User or the city identify a
substantive error in calculation or measurement of wastewater that has affected
the user charges, the party identifying the error shall present documentation
that confirms the error, and the city will either refund the amount of the
error or charge the correct amount to the user, as applicable. Either the
refund paid by the city to the user or the balance due from the user to the
city shall be paid prior to the first day of March in the year in which the
biennial review process is completed, unless other payment arrangements are
mutually agreed to by the city and the user. In no case shall the city issue a
refund to a user for any period in excess of the 12-month period that occurs
immediately prior to identification of an error confirmed by the city as
provided by this division.
   D.   Interim cost adjustments. User charges shall be adjusted by the city
based on revised budgets, as determined necessary by the city.
(Ord. 355, passed - -2010)
Sec. 35-143. NO FREE SERVICE.
   No free service, or service at less than cost, shall be furnished by the
POTW to any person, firm or corporation, public or private, or to any public
agency or instrumentality.
(Ord. 355, passed - -2010)
ARTICLE XXIII. DISCHARGES FROM OTHER LOCAL
UNITS OF GOVERNMENT
Sec. 35-144. WASTEWATER TREATMENT SERVICE AGREEMENTS; LOCAL UNIT SEWER USE
ORDINANCES.
   A.   Any local unit of government, other than the city, that discharges into
the POTW (or that has users or premises located within the local unit that
discharge into the POTW) shall, as a condition to commencing and/or continuing
such discharges, meet all of the following requirements:
      1.   The local unit shall enter into a wastewater treatment service
agreement (WTSA) With the city that sets forth the terms, conditions, and
requirements applicable to current and future discharges from the local unit
(and from any user or premises located within the local unit) to the POTW, and
to the city’s acceptance and treatment of such discharges. The WTSA shall
specify the boundaries of the service district within the local unit that is
eligible to discharge to the POTW. No portion of a local unit’s service
district shall extend outside the political and/or geographical limits of the
local unit; provided that the city may agree to extend a local unit’s service
district to include specified areas located outside the local unit’s boundaries
if the local unit has jurisdiction and regulatory control over sewer service
related matters outside its boundaries (such as through a valid, enforceable
agreement under Public Act 425 of 1984) as determined sufficient by the city,
subject to any terms and conditions as determined necessary by the city to
enable the city to fully meet it’s obligations under applicable laws and
regulations regarding the city’s POTW and the city’s NPDES permit. If a local
unit’s service district is allowed to extend outside the local unit’s
boundaries as provided by this section, the local unit’s WTSA shall, as a
condition to commencing or continuing discharges from the extended service
district to the POTW, be amended accordingly to specify and delineate the
extended service district.
      2.   The local unit shall adopt, and keep continually in force and up-to-
date, an ordinance that, except as specifically provided by this subdivision,
shall be identical to the sewer use regulations as provided by this chapter
(and as this chapter is amended from time to time by the city). (If the local
unit does not have authority to adopt an ordinance, the local unit shall
instead adopt regulations or other provisions with the force of law that meet
the requirements of this subdivision otherwise applicable to a local unit’s
ordinance, as determined sufficient by the city.)
         a.   The ordinance adopted by the local unit (the “local unit’s sewer
use ordinance”) shall expressly designate, empower and authorize the city to
act as the agent and representative of the local unit for purposes of
administering and enforcing the local unit’s sewer use ordinance within the
local unit’s service district. This shall include, but shall not be limited to,
the power and authority of the city, as deemed necessary by the city, to
immediately and independently investigate, enforce, and prosecute
(administratively or judicially, and civilly or criminally) any violation of
this chapter, of the local unit’s sewer use ordinance, or of any notice, order,
permit, decision or determination promulgated, issued or made by the POTW
Superintendent under this chapter or the local unit’s sewer use ordinance, and
to otherwise implement the requirements of this chapter and the local unit’s
sewer use ordinance.
         b.   The local unit’s sewer use ordinance shall expressly require and
provide: that all costs and expenses incidental to the installation, connection
and maintenance, including inspections, of sewer stubs and building leads shall
be at no cost to the city; and that the owner of any premises connected to a
collection system which discharges to the wastewater treatment system must
agree to, and shall be liable to, indemnify the city and hold the city harmless
from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the
installation, connection and maintenance of a sewer stub and building lead,
including, but not limited to, loss or damage from sewer backups not caused by
the city, or any other loss or damage not caused by the city resulting from the
premise’s discharges to the wastewater treatment system, consistent with
applicable laws and regulations.
         c.   The only other deviations and differences permitted between this
chapter and the local unit’s sewer use ordinance shall be those that reflect
the fact that the local unit’s sewer use ordinance is being adopted as an
ordinance by the local unit, and any other deviations or differences that are
approved in advance by the city.
         d.   At the city’s request, the local unit shall terminate service to
any user or premises that fails to comply with the local unit’s sewer use
ordinance.
         e.   If a local unit’s service district is extended as provided by § 
35-144A.1., both the local unit and any other local unit being served pursuant
to the extended service district shall adopt a local sewer use ordinance as
provided by this subdivision; or there shall be a valid, enforceable agreement
under Public Act 425 of 1984 between all of the local units being served as
determined adequate by the city to enable the city to fully meet it’s
obligations under applicable laws and regulations regarding the city’s POTW and
the city’s NPDES permit.
         f.   The local unit shall adopt an ordinance as required by this
section (or make any amendments to revise the ordinance consistent with
revisions to this division as made by the city from time to time) no later than
90 days after written notice from the city.
   B.   It shall be a violation of this chapter for a local unit that
discharges to the POTW (or a user located within the local unit) to fail or
refuse to comply with any provision of this chapter, any provision of the local
unit’s sewer use ordinance, any notice, order, permit, decision or
determination promulgated, issued or made by the POTW Superintendent under this
chapter or the local unit’s sewer use ordinance. Further, it shall be a
violation of this chapter for a local unit to discharge to the POTW except in
full compliance with the terms and requirements of the local unit’s WTSA.
   C.   Notwithstanding any provision of this chapter or other city ordinance
to the contrary, it shall be a violation of this chapter for a local unit, or
any user located within the local unit, to discharge (or continue to discharge)
to the POTW if:
      1.   The discharge is not solely from within the local unit’s service
district as authorized by the local unit’s WTSA; or
      2.   The discharge is from any portion of a collection system owned and/
or operated by or on behalf of a local unit that does not meet the standards
and specifications as required by the local unit’s WTSA or by other applicable
city laws and regulations; or
      3.   The local unit has failed or refused to adopt a local sewer use
ordinance (or subsequently amend such ordinance to conform with subsequent
amendments made by the city to this division), as provided by § 
35-144A.2.; or
      4.   The local unit or user has failed or refused to pay all or any
portion of charges, costs, expenses, penalties, fees, reimbursement, or other
amounts due and payable to the city under this chapter, under the local unit’s
sewer use ordinance, under any notice, order, permit, decision or determination
promulgated, issued or made by the POTW Superintendent under this chapter or
the local unit’s sewer use ordinance, or under the local unit’s WTSA.    
   D.   In addition to any other legal or equitable remedies available to the
city under this chapter or other applicable laws or regulations, the city may
refuse to accept and/or may terminate any discharge from a local unit’s service
district (or from any portion thereof or any user or premises located within
the local unit) to the POTW that does not comply with all of the terms,
conditions, and requirements of this chapter and/or the local unit’s WTSA, as
determined by the POTW.
(Ord. 355, passed - -2010)
ARTICLE XXIV. SEVERABILITY
Sec. 35-145. SEVERABILITY.
   Sections of this chapter shall be deemed severable and should any section,
clause or provision of this chapter be declared to be invalid, the same shall
not affect the validity of the chapter as a whole or any part thereof other
than the part so declared to be invalid.
(Ord. 355, passed - -2010)
ARTICLE XXV. SAVINGS CLAUSE
Sec. 35-146. SAVINGS CLAUSE.
   The amendment or repeal by this chapter of any ordinance or ordinance
provision shall have no effect upon prosecutions commenced prior to the
effective date of this chapter or prosecutions based upon actions taken by any
person prior to the effective date of this chapter. Those prosecutions shall be
conducted under the ordinance provisions in effect prior to the effective date
of this chapter.
(Ord. 355, passed - -2010)
ARTICLE XXVI. CONFLICT
Sec. 35-147. CONFLICT.
   Except as otherwise expressly provided, the provisions of this Ordinance
shall control in the event of any inconsistency or conflict between this
Ordinance and any other provision of any other ordinance of the City.
(Ord. 355, passed - -2010)
ARTICLE XXVII. PUBLICATION
Sec. 35-148. PUBLICATION.
   This section shall be published by publishing a summary of the section in a
newspaper of general circulation in the City of Plainwell, including the
designation in the publication of the location in the city where a true copy of
the chapter Can be inspected or obtained, as authorized by state law.
(Ord. 355, passed - -2010)
ARTICLE XXVIII. EFFECTIVE DATE
Sec. 35-149. EFFECTIVE DATE.
   This chapter shall become effective ten days after the date of publication
of the notice of its adoption as provided in § 
35-148, above, and as certified by the Clerk, in the ordinance codified herein.
(Ord. 355, passed - -2010)
CHAPTER 36: WATER USE
Section

36-2   Ownership

Sec. 36-1. DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CITY BILLING CLERK. The person appointed by the City Manager responsible for
the billing and collection of fees for services as further described herein.
   CITY MANAGER. The City of Plainwell Manager.
   CUSTOMER. The person, persons or entity owning the property in or on which
water is consumed.
   METER. Any measuring device by which the quantity of water used by a
customer is measured.
   PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT. The Public Works Department of the City of
Plainwell.
   SERVICE CONNECTION or SERVICE PIPE. The pipe which delivers water from the
distribution main to the property line of the customer served.
   SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC WORKS. The Department of Public Works
Superintendent.
   WATER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM. The City of Plainwell’s complete potable water
distribution system including all well supplies, mains, service connections,
meters, storage facilities, hydrants, valves, apparatus or appurtenances
connected thereto.
(Ord. 217, eff. 6-1-1984)
Sec. 36-2. OWNERSHIP.
   Management of the water distribution system shall be and remain under the
management, supervision and control of the City Manager who may employ or
designate the person or persons in the capacity or capacities as he or she
deems advisable to carry out the efficient management and operation of the
system. The Administrator shall also make rules, orders or regulations as
deemed advisable and necessary to assure the efficient management and operation
of the system and to provide equitable charges for the service thereof. The
rules, regulations and charges shall be effective upon approval by the City
Council.
(Ord. 217, eff. 6-1-1984)
Sec. 36-3. RIGHT OF ACCESS AND/OR ENTRY TO PREMISES WHERE WATER IS USED.
   Department of Public Works employees of the city shall have the right to
enter any premises in which or on which city water is used, to inspect, adjust,
repair or remove water meters or appurtenances in connection with water
services, at any and all reasonable times. The Department shall have the right
to shut off the supply of water to any premises where the Department is not
able to obtain access to the meter.
(Ord. 217, eff. 6-1-1984)
Sec. 36-4. LIABILITY.
   A.   The city will endeavor to furnish continuous water service to the
customers, but does not guarantee uninterrupted service and will not be liable
for any damage which the customer may sustain by reason of failure of the water
supply or for damages to persons or property arising, occurring or resulting
from the supply of water or from any appurtenance or apparatus in connection
therewith. Whenever possible, a notice of intent to temporarily discontinue
service shall be given affected customers by public notice and/or mailed
notice.
   B.   The city shall not assume liability for intermittent water
discoloration during times of hydrant flushing and/or variations in flow. A
notice of hydrant flushing will be published a minimum of one week prior to
flushing.
(Ord. 217, eff. 6-1-1984)
Sec. 36-5. CHARGES FOR INSTALLATION OF DISTRIBUTION MAINS.
   A.   In all cases where the City Council is petitioned to install
distribution mains in easements or public rights-of-way, for any district or
development not presently served by city water, a charge, based upon cost
estimates for the completed project, providing acceptable service to the
district or development shall be paid for by the party or parties petitioning.
The extent and scope of service necessary for a district or development shall
be prescribed by the City Council in cooperation with the City Engineer, based
on sound engineering and operating practices and the legal requirements of any
other public agency.
   B.   The City Council shall provide water distribution system cost estimates
based upon previous construction costs and the projected changes in costs of
labor and materials prior to authorizing construction. For mains required
larger than ten inches in diameter, that portion of cost for the oversizing
shall be deemed to be “transmission facilities” and the cost differential
therefore shall be absorbed by the city.
   C.   Charges and/or collections for installations of water mains shall be as
follows.
      1.   Where the party or parties require a complete system to service a
plat, multi-family and/or developed complex, these costs shall be borne by the
party or parties. In addition, the actual costs of inspecting the connection
and/or chlorination, pressure testing and other required inspections by the
city shall be borne by the parties.
      2.   Charges for the various distribution construction projects installed
and/or contracted by the city must be paid in full prior to construction,
except where a separate contract is negotiated.
      3.   In case the City Council shall determine, by resolution, that the
expense for distribution mains shall be paid for by special assessment, the
normal assessment policies of the city shall apply.
      4.   In cases where arterial or distribution mains have been installed at
cost to the city, charges for these distribution facilities shall be made when
any abutting property is rendered service from the mains. These charges, for
each front foot of the connecting property, shall be based on costs per lineal
foot for distribution mains in effect at the time of the connection.
(Ord. 217, eff. 6-1-1984)
Sec. 36-6. INSTALLATION AND MAINTENANCE OF SERVICE CONNECTIONS.
   A.   The City of Plainwell Department of Public Works is responsible for the
maintenance of water mains and water services from the main to the water
service shut-off located on the city right-of-way. The property owner is
responsible for the maintenance of the water service from the shut-off to the
building.
   B.   At the request of the owner of the property or his or her duly
authorized representative, water service connections shall be installed and
maintained under the direction and control of the Superintendent of Public
Works. Any change to the site, subsequent to the installation of the
connection, which may affect the operation and maintenance of the service shall
relieve the city from all responsibility for maintenance and liability for any
resultant damages.
(Ord. 217, eff. 6-1-1984)
Sec. 36-7. CONNECTION CHARGES.
   A.   The City Manager is authorized, with the consent of the City Council,
to review the schedule of construction charges for the various sizes and types
of water service connections for each fiscal year. The schedule of rates may
become effective when adopted by resolution of the City Council.
   B.   The total costs for service connection construction shall be paid to
the city before authorization to proceed. All repair costs relating to the
water service connection for any structure shall be the responsibility of the
owner. All costs and any additional costs relating to construction, shall be
due within 30 days after billing.
(Ord. 217, eff. 6-1-1984; Ord. 331, adopted 6-14-2004)
Sec. 36-8. CROSS CONNECTIONS.
   A.   The city adopts by reference the Water Supply Cross Connections Rules
of the State Department of Public Health, being R 32.5.431 to R 32.5.440 of the
Michigan Administrative Code.
   B.   It shall be the duty of the City Manager or agent, to cause inspections
to be made of all properties served by the public water supply where cross
connections with the public water supply is deemed possible. The frequency of
inspections and reinspections based on potential health hazards involved shall
be as established by the City Manager or as required by the State Department of
Public Health.
   C.   The Superintendent of Public Works shall have the right to enter at any
reasonable time any property served by a connection to the public water supply
system of the city for the purpose of inspecting the piping system or systems
thereof for cross connections. On request the owner, lessees or occupants of
any property so served shall furnish to the inspection agency any pertinent
information regarding the piping system or systems on the property. The refusal
of the information or refusal of access, when requested, shall be deemed
evidence of the presence of cross connections.
   D.   The City Manager is authorized and directed to discontinue water
service after reasonable notice to any property wherein any connection in
violation of this section exists and to take other precautionary measures
deemed necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water
supply system. Water service to the property shall not be restored until the
cross connection(s) has been eliminated in compliance with the provisions of
this section.
   E.   The potable water supply made available on the properties served by the
public water system shall be protected from possible contamination as specified
by this section and by the State Plumbing Code.
(Ord. 217, eff. 6-1-1984)
Sec. 36-9. LOCATION AND SIZE OF METERS.
   A.   Meters shall be located in an accessible space, provided by the
property owner at the point where the service connection enters the structure
and shall not be in a crawl space or a locked storage room. When it is
impractical to place the meter elsewhere, the owner shall provide a meter pit
on private property adjacent to the public right-of-way.
   B.   Meter sizes shall be prescribed by the Superintendent of Public Works.
Meter sizes shall be changed when it appears a meter of the wrong size is in
use, except changes shall not be made for seasonal variations.
   C.   The remote meter shall be placed at the direction of the Superintendent
of Public Works.
   D.   Customers are required to have a working ball type shut-off valve both
before and after the water meter.
(Ord. 217, eff. 6-1-1984)
Sec. 36-10. SERVICE OF MORE THAN ONE PREMISES BY THE SAME METER.
   A.   Not more than one residence, factory or industrial institution shall be
serviced by one meter, except under special conditions as approved by the
Superintendent of Public Works.
   B.   When a main is installed on the street past any premises previously
served by a meter also measuring water to another premises, the connection
previously installed shall be removed and the premises connected to the main in
the regular way.
(Ord. 217, eff. 6-1-1984)
Sec. 36-11. PROHIBITION AGAINST BYPASSING METER.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to open any valve or make any connection
which will make possible the use of water which has not passed through a meter
properly installed. In special cases where it is impractical to meter the water
and where the amount used can be accurately estimated, the City Manager may
grant temporary permission in writing for the use of water without a meter.
(Ord. 217, eff. 6-1-1984)
Sec. 36-12. METERS FOR WATER USED DURING CONSTRUCTION/UNMETERED WATER.
   A.   In case of ordinary building construction, a meter shall be set in a
place approved by the city, at the expense of the customer to measure the water
used during construction. Water so used shall be charged at the usual rates.
   B.   In case of an emergency and/or for special temporary purposes, the
Superintendent of Public Works may authorize the use of unmetered water. The
conditions will result in submission of a report to the City Billing Clerk and/
or Administrator.
(Ord. 217, eff. 6-1-1984)
Sec. 36-13. UNLAWFUL TAPPING, REMOVING, INSTALLING AND THE LIKE OF MAINS,
PIPES, METERS AND THE LIKE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, except employees of the city or other
person(s) acting in their official capacity, to tap, change, remove,
disconnect, repair, install, break a seal, turn on or, in any way, disturb any
water mains, branch pipes, services, meters, valves, fittings or other
appurtenances of the water distribution system.
(Ord. 217, eff. 6-1-1984)
Sec. 36-14. FIRE HYDRANTS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, except employees of the city or other
person(s) acting in their official capacity, to operate any fire hydrant, curb
cock or valve which controls water which is unmetered, except as described
below.
   A.   Persons who request to use water from fire hydrants may do so providing
they have written permission from the City Billing Clerk and providing the
users operate the equipment and hydrant according to specific directions of the
Department of Public Works. Water will be charged at established rates.
   B.   Customers may turn water on and off by the valve immediately ahead of
the meter in the basement or meter pit in which the meter is located, at their
pleasure.
(Ord. 217, eff. 6-1-1984)
Sec. 36-15. WATER PIPES AS ELECTRICAL GROUNDS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to ground or electrically connect any
radio, telephone or other electrical system to any pipes or appurtenances
connected to the discharge side of any water meter unless:
   A.   A shunt is placed around the water so as to shunt or bypass any
electrical current that might otherwise flow through the water meter. A shunt
shall be placed so that any meter may be removed without disturbing the
connection. No electrical connection shall be made to the meter or
appurtenances in any way; or
   B.   Ten feet or more of water pipe connected to the discharge side of water
meter is buried in moist earth.
(Ord. 217, eff. 6-1-1984)
Sec. 36-16. CONNECTION CHARGES AND USER RATES.
   A.   Connection charges. All connections to city water mains or repairs to
existing connections shall be made only by the City Department of Public Works
staff after issuance of a written permit by the City Clerk.
      1.   The application for a permit shall include payment of a connection
charge to be established from time to time by resolution of the City Council.
      2.   Application for service shall be made at the City Hall during normal
working hours. For a tap larger than two inches, the difference in cost shall
be paid by the applicant. This includes corporation cock, tail piece and cost
of installation from the main to the curb stop. An additional charge will also
be made for any meter installation greater than two inches.
   B.   User rates. The charge for water service furnished by the city shall be
the sum of the readiness-to-serve charge, dependent upon meter size, plus the
commodity charge, dependent upon the amount of water used applicable to the
rate schedules as established and included.
      1.   Readiness-to-serve charge. The readiness-to-serve charge covers the
fixed costs of maintaining the water system. The readiness-to-serve charge
shall be determined on a frequency and basis that shall be established from
time to time by resolution of the City Council.
      2.   Commodity charge. The commodity charge is based upon the metered
water used and is to be billed in an amount determined from time to time by
resolution of the City Council.
      3.   Hydrant rental. A hydrant rental charge of $8 per month or $96 per
year will be made for each fire hydrant maintained in service.
      4.   Rates and charges. Rates and charges shall be established and
adjusted from time to time by resolution of the City Council.
(Ord. 217, eff. 6-1-1984; Ord. 239, eff. 5-17-1987)
Sec. 36-17. WATER BILLING.
   A.   It is made the duty of the City Billing Clerk to render billing
statements for user fees and all other charges as provided for herein in
connection with the provision of water service and to collect all monies due
therefrom. Said billing statements will be sent monthly on or about the first
day of the month following the month of the provision of the water service and
shall be due and payable at the offices of the City Billing Clerk on or before
the fifteenth day (if a weekend or holiday, then the next business day) of the
month in which the billing statement was rendered. If the full balance of the
billing statement is not paid by the fifteenth day (if a weekend or holiday,
then the next business day) of the month in which it became due and payable: a
late payment service charge of 10% of the balance due shall be added to the
amount owed, with said late payment service charge due immediately and the City
Billing Clerk shall issue a notice of delinquency and intent to discontinue
service. Failure by a customer to receive the notice of delinquency and intent
to discontinue service shall not waive payment of any disconnect charges,
reconnect charges, or other fees or charges.
   B.   If the full balance due and payable including any late payment charges
or other fees or charges for the provision of water service remain unpaid as of
the first Tuesday of the month following when said balance becomes due and
payable, the water service for the lot, parcel of land, or the premises
affected is eligible to be disconnected, and if disconnected, shall not be
turned on again until all sums then due and owing, including penalties and
reconnection fees or charges, are paid. Any disconnection or reconnection fees
shall be in amounts as determined by resolution of the City Council. If water
services are disconnected or reconnected at times other than the regular
business hours of the Public Works Department, there will be imposed an
additional charge for time and materials in an amount to be determined by
resolution of the City Council.
   C.   When the water service to any premises is shut off at the request of
the customer there shall be a water turn-off charge in an amount to be
determined by resolution of the City Council. Where the water service to any
premises is turned on at the request of the customer there shall be a water
turn-on charge in an amount to be determined by resolution of the City Council.
When the city is requested to provide turn-on or shut-off services at times
other than the regular business hours of the City Department of Public Works,
there will be imposed an additional charge for time and materials in an amount
to be determined by resolution of the City Council.
   D.   The user fees and charges for water service which are, under the
provisions of Public Act No. 94 of 1933 (MCL 141.101 et seq.), made a lien on
all premises served thereby, are hereby recognized to constitute such lien and
whenever any such charge against any piece of property shall be delinquent for
a period of six months, the City Council shall certify on or before April 1 of
each year to the city tax assessing officer the fact of such delinquency,
whereupon such delinquent charge shall be entered upon the next tax roll as a
charge against such premises and the lien thereof enforced in the same manner
as general city taxes against such premises are collected and the lien thereof
enforced.
   E.   In the event of a declaration of a state of emergency as authorized by
law, or in the event of a public health or safety emergency as authorized by
the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services or the Allegan County
Health Department, the City Administrator may temporarily suspend water shut
offs to maintain the health and safety of the utility and its customers.
(Ord. 217, eff. 6-1-1984; Ord. 272, eff. 1-1-1992; Ord. 388, passed 11-23-2020;
Ord. 396, passed 8-14-2023)
Sec. 36-18. VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES.
   A.   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter is responsible
for a municipal civil infraction, subject to payment of a civil fine of not
less than $500, plus costs and other sanctions, for each violation. Repeat
offenses shall be subject to increased fines as provided by code.
   B.   A violation of this chapter is also declared to be a public nuisance
and the city may enforce the same by injunction or other remedy, including the
right to correct the violation and bill the owner or person in charge of the
premises.
(Ord. 217, eff. 6-1-1984; Ord. 318, adopted 11-12-2001)
CHAPTER 37: WATER SUPPLY WELLS; CONTAMINATION
Section
   
37-1   Construction or maintenance of source of contamination
   
37-2   Installation or construction of a private water well
   
37-3   Repair, modification or replacement of existing private well
   
37-4   Acts which contribute to contamination
   
37-5   Violations and penalties
   
37-6   Groundwater Protection Board of Appeals
   
37-7   Appeals
Sec. 37-1. CONSTRUCTION OR MAINTENANCE OF SOURCE OF CONTAMINATION.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to construct or
maintain or permit to be constructed or maintained, within a radius of 200 feet
from any of the municipal water wells within the city from which the city draws
its water supplies, any source of possible contamination or pollution to the
wells.
(Ord. 117, adopted 8-11-1952; Am. Ord. 370, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 37-2. INSTALLATION OR CONSTRUCTION OF A PRIVATE WATER WELL.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to install or
construct or permit to be installed or constructed a private water well for the
purpose of drinking water or irrigation, if a public water service connection
is within 200 feet of the property border.
(Ord. 370, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 37-3. REPAIR, MODIFICATION OR REPLACEMENT OF EXISTING PRIVATE WATER WELL.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to repair, modify
or replace 50% or more of the value of an existing private water well for the
purpose of drinking water or irrigation, if a public water service connection
is within 200 feet of the property border.
(Ord. 370, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 37-4. ACTS WHICH CONTRIBUTE TO CONTAMINATION.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to do any act or to
allow to be done any act, that may contaminate or pollute or contribute to the
contamination or pollution of the water supply wells or water system of the
city.
(Ord. 117, adopted 8-11-1952; Am. Ord. 370, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 37-5. VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES.
   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter is responsible for a
municipal civil infraction, subject to payment of a civil fine of not less than
$500, plus costs and other sanctions, for each violation. Repeat offenses shall
be subject to increased fines as provided by code.
(Ord. 117, adopted 8-11-1952)
Sec. 37-6. GROUNDWATER PROTECTION BOARD OF APPEALS.
   A.   In order that the provisions of this article may be reasonably applied
and substantial justice done in instances where unnecessary hardship would
result from carrying out the strict letter of these sections, the City Council
shall appoint a Groundwater Protection Board of Appeals. The duty of the
Groundwater Protection Board of Appeals shall be to consider appeals to
determine, in particular cases, whether any deviation from strict enforcement
will violate the intent of this article or jeopardize the public health or
safety or environment.
   B.   The Groundwater Protection Board of Appeals shall meet at times as the
board may determine. There shall be a fixed place of meeting and all meetings
shall be open to the public in accordance with applicable laws. The Groundwater
Protection Board of Appeals shall adopt its own rules of procedure and keep a
record of its proceedings, showing findings of fact, the action of the Board,
and the vote of each member upon each question considered. The presence of five
members of the Groundwater Protection Board of Appeals shall be necessary to
constitute a quorum.
   C.   The Groundwater Protection Board of Appeals may prescribe the sending
of notice to persons as it deems to be interested in any hearing by the Board.
   D.   The Groundwater Protection Board of Appeals will be appointed by City
Council, may be revised from time to time, and shall include:
      1.   Mayor;
      2.   Chair of the Planning Commission;
      3.   Most senior Planning Commission member other than the Chair;
      4.   Superintendent of Public Works;
      5.   Chair of the Downtown Development Authority Board;
      6.   Chair of the Tax Increment Financing Authority Board; and
      7.   Chair of the Brownfield Redevelopment Authority.
(Ord. 370, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 37-7. APPEALS.
   A.   Formal hearing.
      1.   Appeals from orders of the City Manager may be made at the
groundwater protection board of appeals within 30 days from the date of any
citation, order, charge, fee, surcharge, penalty or other action. The appeal
may be taken by any person aggrieved. The appellant shall file a notice of
appeal with the City Manager and with the groundwater protection board of
appeals, specifying the grounds therefor. Prior to a hearing, the City Manager
shall transmit to the groundwater protection board of appeals a summary report
of all previous action taken. The board of appeals may, at its discretion, call
upon the City Manager to explain the action. The final disposition of the
appeal shall be in the form of a resolution, either reversing, modifying, or
affirming, in whole or in part, the appealed decision or determination. In
order to find for the appellant, a majority of the groundwater protection board
of appeals must concur.
      2.   The groundwater protection board of appeals shall fix a reasonable
time for the hearing of the appeal, give due notice thereof the interested
parties, and decide the appeal within a reasonable time. Within the limits of
its jurisdiction, the groundwater protection board of appeals may reverse or
affirm, in whole or in part, or may make such order, requirements, decisions,
or determination as, in its opinion, ought to be made in the case under
consideration, and to that end shall have all the powers of the official from
whom the appeal is taken.
      3.   The decision of the groundwater protection board of appeals shall be
final, except that the board or the members thereof may be required, under
proper mandamus proceedings, to show cause why certain actions were taken or
decisions rendered.
   B.   Charges outstanding during appeal process. All charges for service,
penalties, fees, or surcharges outstanding during any appeal process shall be
due and payable to the City. Upon resolution of any appeal, the City shall
adjust such amounts accordingly.
   C.   Administrative action. If an informal or formal hearing is not demanded
within the periods specified in this section, the administrative action shall
be deemed final. In the event either or both hearings are demanded, the action
shall be suspended until a final determination has been made, except for
immediate cease and desist orders or any emergency or judicial action.
   D.   Appeals from determinations of groundwater protection board of appeals.
Appeals from the determinations of the groundwater protection board of appeals
may be made to the circuit court for the county as provided by law. The appeals
shall be governed procedurally by the Administrative Procedures Act of 1969
(M.C.L. 24.201 et seq.). All findings of fact, if supported by the evidence,
made by the board shall be conclusive upon the court.
(Ord. 370, adopted 10-27-2014)
CHAPTER 38: GROUNDWATER PROTECTION
Section

38-2   Definitions

38-8   Exemptions and waivers

38-12   Injunctive relief

38-14   Groundwater Protection Board of Appeals
   
38-15   Appeals
   
38-16   Remedies not exclusive
   
38-17   Conflicting regulations
Sec. 38-1. STATEMENT OF PURPOSE.
   A.   The city has determined that certain groundwater underlying areas
including the City of Plainwell currently are, or may be in the future, the
sole source of the city’s drinking water supply. Groundwater aquifers are
integrally connected with the surface water, lakes and streams that constitute
significant public health, recreational and economic resources of the city and
surrounding area. Spills and discharges of hazardous substances threaten the
quality of the groundwater supplies and other water related resources, posing
potential public health and safety hazards and threatening economic losses.
   B.   This chapter protects existing and potential groundwater supplies,
aquifers, and groundwater recharge areas of the city.
(Ord. 369, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 38-2. SUPPLEMENTARY DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ABANDONED OPERATIONS. Any property that is unoccupied for at least 30 days
and to which one or more of the following applies:
      1.   Is open to casual entry;
      2.   Has one or more windows boarded;
      3.   Has utilities disconnected;
      4.   Is unsafe for occupancy or the general public, or is a visual blight
adversely affecting the general welfare of the area;
      5.   Is given notice under the City of Plainwell Zoning Ordinances
Dangerous Buildings Chapter;
      6.   Is the subject of indebtedness to the city for more than one year.
   ABANDONED OPERATIONS do not include a property that is actively listed by a
licensed real estate broker.
   AQUIFER. A geological formation, group of formations, or part of a formation
capable of storing and yielding a significant amount of groundwater to wells
and springs.
   CHEMICAL ABSTRACT SERVICE (CAS) NUMBER. A unique number for every chemical
established by a Columbus, Ohio organization which indexes information
published in Chemical Abstracts by the American Chemical Society.
   HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCE. A chemical or other material that is or may become
injurious to the public health, safety, or welfare, or to the environment. The
term HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCE includes, but is not limited to, any of the following
which are stored or generated in quantities greater than 100 kilograms
(approximately 220 pounds or 25 gallons) per month, and which require site plan
review under provisions of this chapter.
      1.   Hazardous substances as defined in the Comprehensive Environmental
Response, Compensation and Liability Act (CERCLA) of 1980, Public Law 96.510,
94 State. 2767;
      2.   Hazardous waste as defined in Part 111 of the State of Michigan
Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act, 1994 Public Act 451, as
amended;
      3.   Regulated substance as defined in Part 213 of the State of Michigan
Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act, 1994 Public Act 451, as
amended;
      4.   Hazardous substance as defined in Part 201 of the State of Michigan
Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act, 1994 Public Act 451, as
amended;
      5.   Used oil;
      6.   Radiological materials.
   POLLUTION INCIDENT PREVENTION PLAN (PIPP). A PIPP includes a polluting
material inventory, a site diagram depicting the locations of the polluting
materials, emergency response procedures, and secondary-containment details.
Sites are subject to Michigan’s Part 5 Rules if they store oils and other
polluting materials above established threshold management quantities (TMQs),
which are:
      1.   Salt in solid form at quantities of five tons (10,000 pounds) or
more.
      2.   Salt in liquid form at 1,000 gallons or more.
      3.   Petroleum products in an AST or container with a capacity of 660
gallons or greater or an aggregate aboveground storage capacity of 1,320
gallons.
      4.   All other polluting materials specified in Part 5 that are used,
stored, or otherwise managed in a discrete outdoor location, with a total
storage quantity of 200 kilograms (kg) (440 pounds) or more.
      5.   All other polluting materials specified in Part 5 that are used,
stored, or otherwise maintained at a discrete indoor location, with a total
storage quantity of 1,000 kg (2,200 pounds) or more.
   PROPERLY PLUGGED ABANDONED WELL. A well that has been closed in accordance
with regulations and procedures of the Michigan Department of Environmental
Quality and the local Health Department. A PROPERLY PLUGGED ABANDONED WELL
requires a permit to be brought back into service.
   SECONDARY CONTAINMENT. A second tank, catchment pit, pipe, or vessel that
limits and contains liquid or chemical leaking or leaching from a primary
containment area; monitoring and recovery are required.
   SPILL PREVENTION CONTROL AND COUNTERMEASURE (SPCC) PLAN. As detailed in 40
CFR Part 112, sites are subject to the SPCC rules if (1) they store either more
than 1,320 gallons of petroleum products aboveground and (2) they present a
reasonable risk to a navigable water of the United States property (including
via storm water and groundwater). A SPCC PLAN details site oil storage, spill
potential, and emergency response and notification procedures. The SPCC PLAN is
required to be certified by a registered professional engineer.
   STORM WATER POLLUTION PREVENTION PLAN (SWPPP). As detailed in 40 CFR Part
122, sites that are required to have a storm water permit are also required to
have SWPPPs that detail hazardous substance exposed to storm water and controls
to prevent releases.
   UNDERGROUND STORAGE TANK. A tank or combination of tanks, including
underground pipes connected to the tank or tanks, which is, was, or may have
been used to contain an accumulation of hazardous substances, as defined in
Part 211 of the State of Michigan Natural Resources and Environmental
Protection Act, 1994 Public Act 451, as amended.
   UNPLUGGED ABANDONED WELL. A well which has not been used for one year or
more.
   WELL. As defined in the Michigan Water Well Construction and Pump
Installation Code, Part 127, Act 368 of the Public Acts of 1978, as amended,
and rules; or a permanent or temporary opening in the surface of the earth for
the purpose of removing water, or testing water quality, or measuring water
characteristics, or measuring liquid recharge, or measuring liquid levels, or
oil and gas exploration or production, or waste disposal, or dewatering
purposes; or geothermal heat exchange purposes, or a cistern of a depth of four
feet or more and with a top width of 12 inches or more.
   WELLHEAD PROTECTION AREA. The area which has been approved by the MDEQ in
accordance with the State of Michigan Wellhead Protection Program, which
represents the surface and subsurface area surrounding a water well or well
field, which supplies a public water system, and through which contaminants are
reasonably likely to move toward and reach the water well or well field within
a ten-year time of travel.
(Ord. 369, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 38-3. APPLICABILITY.
   USES SUBJECT TO SITE PLAN REVIEW: Except as provided in Section
38-8, “EXEMPTIONS AND WAIVERS”, this chapter applies to all building permit
requests made under
Chapter 53: Zoning.
(Ord. 369, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 38-4. PROHIBITIONS WITHIN TEN YEAR TIME-OF-TRAVEL (TOT) WELLHEAD
PROTECTION AREA.
   For any parcel of land that has a portion within a ten-year wellhead
protection area, the following are prohibited at any location on the parcel:
   A.   Operations of a scrap and recycling yard.
   B.   Operations of a State of Michigan Type II or Type III solid waste
landfill.
   C.   Use of oil, waste oil, or similar liquid petroleum-type products for
dust suppression.
   D.   Excavation, extraction, or mining of sand, gravel, bedrock, or any
other type of earth if a permit or site plan review is required.
   E.   Unplugged abandoned wells.
   F.   Drilling for natural gas or petroleum, whether for exploration or
production.
   G.   Drilling, direct-push and other earth penetration beyond 15 feet depth
shall be sealed to within two feet of surface grade with grout, or with soil
material exhibiting lower hydraulic permeability than the native soil.
(Ord. 369, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 38-5. SITE PLAN REVIEW.
   Site plan review procedures. Applicable projects under this chapter that
also require site plan review under Chapter 53 shall include:
   A.   Existing and proposed land use deed restrictions, if any.
   B.   Location and outline of all existing septic tanks and drain fields.
   C.   Location of any floor drains in proposed structures on the site. The
point of discharge for all drains and pipes shall be specified on the site
plan.
   D.   Location of existing and proposed public and private drinking water
wells, monitoring wells, irrigation wells, test wells, wells used for
industrial processes or wells that have no identified use.
   E.   Inventory of hazardous substances to be stored, used or generated on-
site, presented in a format acceptable to the City Planning Commission and
Department of Public Safety (include CAS numbers).
   F.   Description and drawings showing size and location for any existing or
proposed aboveground and underground storage tanks, piping lines and
dispensers.
   G.   Descriptions of type of operations proposed for the project and
drawings showing size, location, and description of any proposed interior or
exterior areas of structures for storing, using, loading or unloading of
hazardous substances.
   H.   Reported delineation of areas on the site which are known or suspected
to be contaminated, together with a report on the status of cleanup or closure.
   I.   Completion of the City of Plainwell Environmental Permits Checklist.
(Ord. 369, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 38-6. CRITERIA FOR REVIEW.
   Criteria for review will include:
   A.   The project and related improvements shall be designed to protect land
and water resources from pollution, including pollution of soils, groundwater,
rivers, streams, lakes, ponds, and wetlands.
   B.   If required by state or federal law, properties using hazardous
substances are required to have a Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasure
(SPCC) Plan, a Pollution Incident Prevention Plan (PIPP), and/or a Storm Water
Pollution Prevention Plan (SWPPP).
   C.   Sites that at any time use, store or generate hazardous substances
shall be designed to prevent spills and unpermitted discharges to air, surface
of the ground, groundwater, lakes, streams, rivers or wetlands.
   D.   Hazardous substances stored on the site before, during, or after site
construction, shall be stored in a location and manner designed to prevent
spills and unpermitted discharges to air, surface of the ground, groundwater,
lakes, streams, rivers, or wetlands.
   E.   Secondary containment facilities shall be provided for aboveground
storage of hazardous substances in accordance with state and federal
requirements. Aboveground secondary containment facilities shall be designed
and constructed so that the potentially polluting material cannot escape from
the unit by gravity through sewers, drains, or other means, directly or
indirectly into a sewer system, or to the waters of the State (including
groundwater).
   F.   Unplugged abandoned wells and cisterns shall be plugged in accordance
with regulations and procedures of the Michigan Department of Environmental
Quality and the County Health Department.
   G.   Completion of the City of Plainwell Environmental Permits Checklist.
(Ord. 369, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 38-7. PROFESSIONAL REVIEW OF PROPOSED DEVELOPMENT.
   Fees in escrow for professional reviews. Any application for site plan
approval under this chapter may require the deposit of fees to be held in
escrow in the name of the applicant. An escrow fee shall be required by the
Building Official unless waived by the Building Official or City Council.
Waiver shall be based on a written conclusion that there is no substantial
information or analysis benefit to accrue as a result of the application of
this section. An escrow fee may be requested to obtain a professional review of
any other project which may, at the discretion of the Building Official create
an identifiable and potentially negative impact on public infrastructure or
services, or on adjacent properties and because of which, professional input is
desired before a decision to approve, deny or approve with conditions is made.
   A.   The escrow shall be used to pay professional review expenses of
engineers, community planners, and any other professionals whose expertise the
city values to review the proposed application and/or site plan of an
applicant. Professional review will result in a report to the City indicating
the extent of conformance or nonconformance with this chapter and to identify
any problems that may create a threat to public health, safety or the general
welfare. Mitigation measures or alterations to a proposed design may be
identified where they would serve to lessen or eliminate identified impacts.
The applicant will receive a copy of any professional review hired by the city
and a copy of the statement of expenses for the professional services rendered.
   B.   No application for approval for which an escrow fee is requested will
be processed until the escrow fee is deposited with the City Clerk. The amount
of the escrow fee shall be established based on an estimate of the cost of the
services to be rendered by the professionals contacted by the Building
Official. The applicant is entitled to a refund of any unused escrow fees at
the time a permit is either issued or denied in response to the applicant’s
request.
   C.   If actual professional review costs exceed the amount of an escrow, the
applicant shall pay the balance due prior to receipt of any land use or other
permit issued by the city in response to the applicant’s request.
   D.   Disputes on the costs of professional reviews may be resolved by an
arbitrator mutually satisfactory to both parties.
(Ord. 369, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 38-8. EXEMPTIONS AND WAIVERS.
   A.   A limited exclusion from this chapter is hereby authorized as follows:
      1.   The site plan review criteria of Section
38-5 and
38-6 do not apply to hazardous substances packaged for personal or household
use or present in the same form and concentration as a product packaged for use
by the general public.
      2.   The site plan review requirements of Section
38-5 and
38-6 do not apply to products held in containers with a volume of less than 40
gallons and packaged for retail use.
      3.   The total excluded substances containing hazardous substances may
not exceed the lesser of 200 gallons or 1,000 pounds at any time.
   B.   Residential family dwellings (R-1, R-2 and RMH) and PUD districts
proposed for development outside of the city’s wellhead protection areas are
exempt from the site plan review requirements of Sec.
38-5.
(Ord. 369, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 38-9. ABANDONED OPERATIONS.
   This section applies to residences, businesses or other operations. Those
who own or control abandoned operations shall do the following:
   A.   Within seven days of becoming an abandoned operation, take such steps
as necessary to secure the site such that natural elements such as water, wind
and ice or vandals and all other persons cannot gain access to the hazardous
substances.
   B.   Within 30 days of becoming inactive, provide to the code official and
the Department of Public Safety a document that identifies the site, the date
of inactivity, the hazardous substances that exist on site, and the name,
address, and telephone number of both the owner and the person in control of
the site.
   C.   Within 60 days of becoming inactive, remove all hazardous substances
from the site. This does not include those substances used for heating,
cooling, and/or electrical lighting.
(Ord. 369, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 38-10. ENFORCEMENT.
   A.   Whenever the city determines that a person has violated a provision of
Section 38-9, the City Building Inspector shall issue a written notice of
violation.
   B.   The notice shall be directed to the owner or party in interest of the
building in whose name the property appears on the last local tax assessment
records of the city.
   C.   If abatement of a violation and/or restoration of affected property are
required, the notice shall set forth a deadline by which such remediation or
restoration must be completed. The notice shall further advise that, should the
responsible party fail to remediate or restore within the established deadline,
the work may be done by the city, with the expense thereof charged to the
property owner and possibly assessed as a lien against the property.
   D.   All notices required by Sec.
38-10 shall be in writing and shall be served upon the person to whom they are
directed personally or in lieu of personal service, may be mailed by certified
mail, return receipt requested, addressed to the owner or party in interest at
the address shown on the tax records, at least ten days before the date of the
hearing described in the notice. If any person to whom a notice is directed is
not personally served, in addition to mailing the notice, a copy thereof shall
be posted upon a conspicuous part of the building or structure at least ten
days prior to the hearing date.
(Ord. 369, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 38-11. ABATEMENT/REMEDIAL ACTIVITIES BY THE CITY.
   A.   The city is authorized to take or contract with others to take
reasonable and necessary abatement or remedial activities whenever the city
determines a violation of this chapter has occurred and that the responsible
party cannot or will not correct the violation in a timely manner, or when no
known responsible party exists. The responsible party shall reimburse the city
for all reasonable expenses thus incurred by the city. A lien may be placed on
the property for the reimbursement of all reasonable expenses.
   B.   If the city desires the responsible party to reimburse it for
reasonable abatement activity expenses, the city shall, within 90 days of the
completion of the activities, mail to that person a notice of claim outlining
the expenses incurred, including reasonable administrative costs, and the
amounts thereof. The person billed shall pay said sum in full within 30 days of
receipt of the claim. If the person billed desires to object to all or some of
the amount sought by the city, said person may file, within the same 30 day
period, a written objection so stating. The city shall, within 30 days of its
receipt of the objection, provide an opportunity for the objecting party to
present facts or arguments supporting the objection. If the city determines
that some or the entire amount originally billed is appropriate, the person
shall pay the sum within 30 days of receipt of that determination. If the
amount due is not paid, the city may cause the charges to become a special
assessment against the property and shall constitute a lien on the property.
(Ord. 369, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 38-12. INJUNCTIVE RELIEF.
   If a person has violated or continues to violate the provisions of this
chapter, the city may petition the appropriate court for injunctive relief
restraining the person from activities that would create further violations, or
compelling the person to perform necessary abatement or remediation.
(Ord. 369, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 38-13. VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES.
   Violation of this chapter shall be subject to the Municipal Civil Infraction
Chapter of the city’s code of ordinances.
(Ord. 369, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 38-14. GROUNDWATER PROTECTION BOARD OF APPEALS.
   A.   In order that the provisions of this chapter may be reasonably applied
and substantial justice done in instances where unnecessary hardship would
result from carrying out the strict letter of these sections, the City Council
shall appoint a Groundwater Protection Board of Appeals. The duty of the
Groundwater Protection Board of Appeals shall be to consider appeals from the
decision of the City Manager and to determine, in particular cases, whether any
deviation from strict enforcement will violate the intent of this chapter or
jeopardize the public health or safety or environment.
   B.   The Groundwater Protection Board of Appeals shall meet at times as the
board may determine. There shall be a fixed place of meeting and all meetings
shall be open to the public in accordance with applicable laws. The Groundwater
Protection Board of Appeals shall adopt its own rules of procedure and keep a
record of its proceedings, showing findings of fact, the action of the Board,
and the vote of each member upon each question considered. The presence of five
members of the Groundwater Protection Board of Appeals shall be necessary to
constitute a quorum.
   C.   The Groundwater Protection Board of Appeals may prescribe the sending
of notice to persons as it deems to be interested in any hearing by the Board.
   D.   The Groundwater Protection Board of Appeals will be appointed by City
Council, may be revised from time to time, and shall include:
      1.   Mayor;
      2.   Chair of the Planning Commission;
      3.   Most senior Planning Commission member other than the Chair;
      4.   Superintendent of Public Works;
      5.   Chair of the Downtown Development Authority Board;
      6.   Chair of the Tax Increment Financing Authority Board; and
      7.   Chair of the Brownfield Redevelopment Authority.
(Ord. 369, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 38-15. APPEALS.
   A.   Right of appeal. Any person has the right to appeal the basis for any
charges, permits, orders, or other action developed in accordance with this
chapter. Appeals shall be directed to the City Manager along with any
supporting documentation for amendment of the charges in question. Any
additional information that may be required to resolve the appeal, as directed
by the City Manager, shall be obtained by the user at his expense. Resolution
of appeals shall be made within 30 days in accordance with the best available
data and the formulations presented in this chapter.
   B.   Informal hearing.
      1.   An informal hearing before the City Manager may be requested in
writing by any person deeming itself aggrieved by any citation, order, charge,
fee, surcharge, penalty, or action within ten days after the date thereof,
stating the reasons therefor with supporting documents and data.
      2.   The informal hearing shall be scheduled at the earliest practicable
date, but not later than five days after receipt of the request, unless
extended by mutual written agreement.
      3.   The hearing shall be conducted on an informal basis at the City Hall
or such place as designated by the City Manager.
   C.   Formal hearing. 
      1.   Appeals from orders of the City Manager may be made at the
Groundwater Protection Board of Appeals within 30 days from the date of any
citation, order, charge, fee, surcharge, penalty or other action. The appeal
may be taken by any person aggrieved. The appellant shall file a notice of
appeal with the City Manager and with the Groundwater Protection Board of
Appeals, specifying the grounds therefor. Prior to a hearing, the City Manager
shall transmit to the Groundwater Protection Board of Appeals a summary report
of all previous action taken. The Board of Appeals may, at its discretion, call
upon the City Manager to explain the action. The final disposition of the
appeal shall be in the form of a resolution, either reversing, modifying, or
affirming, in whole or in part, the appealed decision or determination. In
order to find for the appellant, a majority of the Groundwater Protection Board
of Appeals must concur.
      2.   The Groundwater Protection Board of Appeals shall fix a reasonable
time for the hearing of the appeal, give due notice thereof the interested
parties, and decide the appeal within a reasonable time. Within the limits of
its jurisdiction, the Groundwater Protection Board of Appeals may reverse or
affirm, in whole or in part, or may make such order, requirements, decisions,
or determination as, in its opinion, ought to be made in the case under
consideration, and to that end shall have all the powers of the official from
whom the appeal is taken.
      3.   The decision of the Groundwater Protection Board of Appeals shall be
final, except that the Board or the members thereof may be required, under
proper mandamus proceedings, to show cause why certain actions were taken or
decisions rendered.
   D.   Charges outstanding during appeal process. All charges for service,
penalties, fees, or surcharges outstanding during any appeal process shall be
due and payable to the city. Upon resolution of any appeal, the city shall
adjust such amounts accordingly.
   E.   Administrative action. If an informal or formal hearing is not demanded
within the periods specified in this section, the administrative action shall
be deemed final. In the event either or both hearings are demanded, the action
shall be suspended until a final determination has been made, except for
immediate cease and desist orders or any emergency or judicial action.
   F.   Appeals from determinations of Groundwater Protection Board of Appeals.
Appeals from the determinations of the Groundwater Protection Board of Appeals
may be made to the circuit court for the county as provided by law. The appeals
shall be governed procedurally by the Administrative Procedures Act of 1969
(MCL 24.201 et seq.). All findings of fact, if supported by the evidence, made
by the Board shall be conclusive upon the court.
(Ord. 369, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 38-16. REMEDIES NOT EXCLUSIVE.
   The remedies listed in this chapter are not exclusive of any other remedies
available under any applicable federal, state, or local law, and it is within
the discretion of the city to seek cumulative remedies.
(Ord. 369, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 38-17. CONFLICTING RESOLUTIONS.
   Whenever any provision of this chapter imposes more stringent requirements,
regulations, restrictions or limitations than are imposed or required by the
provisions of any other law or chapter, then the provisions of this chapter
shall govern. Whenever the provisions of any other law or chapter impose more
stringent requirements than are imposed or required by this title, then the
provision of such chapter shall govern.
(Ord. 369, adopted 10-27-2014)
CHAPTER 39: GEOTHERMAL HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS PERMITS
Section
   
39-1   Purpose
   
39-2   Definitions
   
39-3   Geothermal heat pump system permit required
   
39-4   Application procedure
   
39-5   Permit requirements
   
39-6   Permit fee
   
39-7   Permit revocation
   
39-8   Open loop systems prohibited
   
39-9   Periodic system testing
   
39-10   Backflow prevention
   
39-11   System abandonment
   
39-12   Violations and penalties
   
39-13   Remedies not exclusive
   
39-14   Conflicting regulations
Sec. 39-1. STATEMENT OF PURPOSE.
   A.   The city has determined that an open loop geothermal system that
penetrates and/or draws water from an aquifer can deplete or pollute
groundwater. Additionally, an improperly constructed or maintained closed loop
geothermal system can pollute groundwater.
   B.   This chapter protects the public health, safety, and general welfare
including existing and potential groundwater supplies, aquifers, and
groundwater recharge areas of the city from pollution or depletion resulting
from construction, reconstruction, repair, or abandonment of geothermal heat
pump systems.
(Ord. 368, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 39-2. SUPPLEMENTARY DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ANNULAR SPACE. The space between the casing or well screen and the wall of
the borehole, or between drilling pipe and casing, or between two separate
strings of casing.
   AQUIFER. A geological formation, group of formations, or part of a formation
capable of storing and yielding a significant amount of groundwater to wells
and springs.
   AS-BUILT PLAN. A legible hand-sketch or computer generated illustration.
   BENTONITE GROUT. A slurry that consists of sodium montmorillonite bentonite
and water and that has a solids concentration of not less than 20%. A slurry of
drilling fluid bentonite and water or drilled cuttings, either singularly or in
combination, is not BENTONITE GROUT.
   BOREHOLE. A hole drilled or bored into the earth, usually into which casing,
screen, piping and other materials may be installed to construct a well or
geothermal heat pump system.
   CASING. An impervious, durable pipe placed in a borehole to prevent the
walls of the borehole from caving, and to seal off surface drainage or
undesirable water, gas, or other fluids and prevent entrance into a well.
   CLOSED LOOP SYSTEM. A geothermal heat pump system that generally consists of
underground loops of piping; heat transfer fluid; a heat pump, and an air
distribution system. An opening is made in the earth. One or more pipes are
installed into the opening and connected to a heat exchange system in the
building. The pipes form a “closed loop” and are filled with a heat transfer
fluid. The fluid is circulated through the piping from the opening into the
heat exchanger and back. The system functions in the same manner as the open
loop system except there is no pumping of groundwater.
   DEPARTMENT. The Michigan Department of Environmental Quality or its
predecessor.
   DRINKING WATER. Water which is intended for human consumption and other
domestic uses, and is considered to be free of harmful chemicals and disease-
causing microorganisms.
   GEOTHERMAL HEAT PUMP SYSTEM. A mechanical system for space heating or
cooling that relies on the transfer of thermal energy between the earth and a
heat transfer fluid and consists of heat pump, a well to exchange heat and a
heat distribution network.
   GROUNDWATER. Water beneath the earth’s surface that is located between
saturated soil and rock that supplies wells and springs.
   GROUT. A low permeability material that is emplaced in the space between the
wall of the borehole and the casing of a well end, or placed in the annular
space of the borehole. The emplacement of GROUT is to prevent the migration of
water or fluid contaminants into and through the borehole. GROUT shall consist
of neat cement or high solids bentonite slurry.
   HEAT TRANSFER FLUID. Any liquid used especially for the purpose of
transferring thermal energy from the heat source to another location.
   ISOLATION DISTANCES. The distance of a source of contamination from a
surface drinking water source, a groundwater source supply well, or any type of
borehole.
   NEAT CEMENT GROUT. A mixture of one bag of Portland cement (94 pounds) and
not more than six gallons of fresh water. Drilling fluid bentonite that is not
more than 5% by weight of cement and additional water that is not more than 0.6
gallons for each 1% of bentonite may be added to neat cement grout.
   OPEN LOOP SYSTEM. A geothermal heat pump system in which groundwater is
drawn from a well into a heat exchanger that is often located in a surface
building. The water drawn from the earth is then pumped back into the aquifer
through a different well or in some cases the same well. Alternatively, the
groundwater could be discharged to a surface water body. In the heating mode,
cooler water is returned to the earth, while in the cooling mode, warmer water
is returned to the surface water body.
   PERMEABILITY. The propensity of a material to allow fluid to move through
its pores or interstices. PERMEABILITY is an important soil parameter when flow
of water through soil or rock is a matter of concern.
   PERMIT. For the purpose of
Chapter 39, PERMIT means a city permit issued to construct, install, modify,
replace or repair a geothermal heat pump system; or dig, bore, drill, replace,
modify, repair, or destroy a well that is intended to be or was part of a
geothermal heat pump system.
   PUBLIC WATER SUPPLY WELL. Water supply well used or made available to two or
more consumers.
      1.   TYPE I. Community water supply providing year-round service to not
less than 25 residents or not less than 15 living units.
      2.   TYPE IIb. Non-community water supply providing year-round service to
not less than 25 residents or not less than 15 living units.
      3.   TYPE III. Anything not considered Type I or Type II water supply;
serves less than 25 people and less than 15 connections, or operates for less
than 60 days per year.
   WASTE WATER SYSTEM. Any system for the collection, storage, treatment,
neutralization or stabilization of sewage that occurs on a property.
      1.   SEPTIC SYSTEM. Type of waste water system consisting of a septic
tank that collects all of the sewage. The sewage separates into solid (sludge)
that settles to the bottom and liquid effluent that then flows into a leach
field for final treatment by the soil.
      2.   MUNICIPAL SYSTEM. Type of waste water system whereby sewage flows
into a sanitary sewer system and is carried to a waste water treatment plant
for chemical and/or biological treatment.
   WATER SUPPLY WELL. A well used to provide potable water for drinking or
domestic purposes.
   WELL. As defined in the Michigan Water Well Construction and Pump
Installation Code, Part 127, Act 368 of the Public Acts of 1978, as amended,
and rules; or a permanent or temporary opening in the surface of the earth for
the purpose of removing water, testing water quality, measuring water
characteristics, measuring liquid levels, oil and gas exploration or
production, waste disposal, dewatering, or for geothermal heat exchange
purposes, or for a cistern of a depth four feet or more and with a top width of
12 inches or more.
(Ord. 368, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 39-3. GEOTHERMAL HEAT PUMP SYSTEM PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall construct or install a geothermal heat pump system without
first obtaining a permit from the city. No permit shall be issued for any open
loop geothermal heat pump system per Section
39-8 below.
   A.   An application for a geothermal permit shall be made to the city on
city approved forms.
   B.   Permits shall be issued to the owner or an agent thereof for the
particular parcel of property on which the geothermal heat pump system is to be
constructed and/or installs.
   C.   Open-loop systems existing prior to the date of the adoption of this
chapter shall be allowed.
(Ord. 368, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 39-4. APPLICATION PROCEDURE.
   A.   Applications for city permits shall be made to the City Clerk on City
approved forms.
   B.   Application may be made by the property owner or an agent thereof.
(Ord. 368, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 39-5. PERMIT REQUIREMENTS.
   A.   Permits may be issued only for closed loop geothermal heat pump systems
that are entirely located within the boundaries of the property.
   B.   Boreholes shall be drilled by Michigan registered/licensed water well
drillers.
   C.   The property owner shall maintain and also submit to the city a well
log of the borehole and as built plans showing the location and specifications
of closed loop geothermal heat pump system components.
   D.   Abandoned wells are to be plugged.
   E.   Wells shall be constructed in accordance with the procedures in Part
127, Water Supply and Sewer Systems, of the Public Health Code, 1978 PA 368.
   F.   Abandoned wells shall be plugged in accordance with the procedures in
Part 127, Water Supply and Sewer Systems, of the Public Health Code, 1978 PA
368.
   G.   Borehole piping shall be high density polyethylene as specified in
International Ground Source Heat Pump Association standards for closed loop
heat pumps.
   H.   The annular space of the boreholes shall be sealed for the full depth
of the borehole using high solid bentonite grout.
   I.   Meet the following minimum isolation distances during construction:
      1.    Twenty-five feet from an on-site wastewater system;
      2.    Ten feet from property line; and
      3.    Ten feet from road right of ways and utilities.
   J.   For geothermal heat pump systems with components extending over 15 feet
below grade surface, meet the following minimum isolation distances during
construction:
      1.    Fifty feet from a household drinking water well;
      2.    Seventy-five feet from a Type IIb or Type III public water supply
well, as defined in R 325.10502of the Michigan Administrative Code; and
      3.    Two hundred feet from a Type I or Type IIa public water supply
well, as defined in R325.10502 of the Michigan Administrative Code.
   K.   For geothermal heat pump systems with components extending over 15 feet
below grade surface, documentation that the components will be located where
they are not subject to contamination and/or will not penetrate into a zone of
contamination. Websites such as the Environmental Mapper website at http://
mcgi.state.mi.us/environmentalmapping/ may be used for determining if
contaminated sites are in the vicinity of the proposed installation.
(Ord. 368, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 39-6. PERMIT FEE.
   The geothermal heat pump system permit fee shall be in the amount
established from time-to-time by resolution of the City Council and shall be
paid when the application is filed.
(Ord. 368, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 39-7. PERMIT REVOCATION.
   A.   The city may revoke a permit if:
      1.    Any action or any geothermal heat pump system violates a provision
of this chapter; or
      2.    There are factual inaccuracies in a permit application or the
documents supporting it.
   B.   The city shall notify the property owner and occupant in writing of a
permit revocation.
      1.   The property owner or agent may appeal a revocation to the City
Manager who shall hold a hearing on that revocation to allow the appellant to
prove the geothermal heat pump system complies with this chapter or that the
statements in the application and supporting documents are true. Further
appeals shall be to the Allegan County Circuit Court.
      2.   When a permit is revoked, the property owner or agent shall
immediately abandon the geothermal heat pump system as required by this
chapter. Except in cases where the city reasonably determines that groundwater
contamination is an imminent risk, the obligation to abandon the geothermal
heat pump system after revocation shall be stayed while any appeal is pending.
(Ord. 368, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 39-8. OPEN LOOP SYSTEMS PROHIBITED.
   Open loop geothermal heat pump systems are prohibited.
(Ord. 368, adopted 10-27-2014)
Sec. 39-9. PERIODIC SYSTEM TESTING.
   A.   All closed-loop systems pipes for geothermal heat pump system permitted
under this chapter shall be tested hydrostatically at one and one-half times
